description: In this series we will be covering the use of network mapper utility aptly called Nmap. This series aims to give the viewer a firm grasp of the concepts and applications inherent to Nmap, such as Host Discovery, Port Scanning, Service/OS/Version Detection, and the Nmap Scripting Engine(NSE) for the purposes of security and general network administration.
name: Nmap
subtitle: Network Mapper, a Security Scanner

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Dan explore the administrative utility known as Nmap. They discuss what the Nmap software is and might use this software. They demonstrate how to obtain the software as well the types of operating systems that support Nmap and their associated installer types. They will show how to install Nmap in the major operating systems such as Windows, Ubuntu and CentOS.
episodes.title: Installing Nmap

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Dan continue their discussion on the basics of Nmap. They will explore basic introductory scans. They look at scanning a range of IP address as well as scanning small portions of a subnet.  They will demonstrate coupling utilities like nslookup, host and dig with Nmap as well as explaining some of the interactions with DNS that a user needs to be aware of when using Nmap.
episodes.title: Nmap Basics Part 2

I don't know, cuz I do it.

It'll tell you actually my

Specifies the query type so

00:32:10.028 --> 00:32:13.736
So I'm gonna do host -t

00:32:13.736 --> 00:32:18.217
now it's making sense because now
what you have to add is axfr.

00:32:18.217 --> 00:32:24.090
Yeah I believe axfr,
this is the type of scan we're doing.

00:32:24.090 --> 00:32:27.800
This is in the RFC's for
DNS and doing zone transfers.

00:32:27.800 --> 00:32:31.600
This is the type of record
lookup that we wanna do so

00:32:31.600 --> 00:32:33.080
that's why we're throwing in out there.

00:32:33.080 --> 00:32:34.890
This is a full zone transfer.

And then we give it the actual host that

622
00:32:42.040 --> 00:32:44.360
So if it was ITPro.tv,

00:32:44.360 --> 00:32:48.360
For this I'm gonna use just because it

it is zonetransfer.me.

And he is that site,
that digi ninja has so

631

Connection refused.

I probably added too much.

All right, so

Just easiest if I maybe I got the wrong.

mszt.ml.digi.ninja.

Well this is maybe they

right now maybe its only

00:33:33.000 --> 00:33:35.080
Normally though I did this earlier.

Came back with his own thoughts, gigantic.

Let's try another one.

00:33:37.630 --> 00:33:38.740
Let's use dig.

00:33:38.740 --> 00:33:40.130
The host, that's how would you do it.

644
00:33:40.130 --> 00:33:40.760
Let's try dig.

645
00:33:40.760 --> 00:33:45.520
Dig tends to be the most popular
way in which you will do this, so

00:33:45.520 --> 00:33:49.460
I like dig the best, I'm not as familiar
with host, I don't use host a whole lot,

00:33:51.870 --> 00:33:54.060
So that's why I wanted

00:33:54.060 --> 00:34:00.500
So let's try dig, let's see dig,
and we'll do the axfr like so.

And then this time we do @
what the NDS server is and

00:34:05.970 --> 00:34:11.510
that is nsztml.digi.ninja.

00:34:12.390 --> 00:34:18.725
No I didn't, that's okay were good to

00:34:19.750 --> 00:34:24.840
Fingers crossed, yeah so it looks

the day, maybe on lunch for

But I was able to do a full zonetransfer

So, just if you're testing this out,

try throughout the day.

If you're not getting connection,

It's a free service.

00:34:41.230 --> 00:34:43.880
I was hoping it would work for

It's not a big deal but that's how you

It's showing us this is normally what

I don't wanna give you a zone transfer.

00:34:52.010 --> 00:34:54.590
That's normally how you're gonna see this.

But that one time you're
doing a pen test or

00:34:57.210 --> 00:35:02.260
doing a scan and it comes back with

00:35:02.260 --> 00:35:04.060
Actually we can go to their site.

00:35:04.060 --> 00:35:06.420
They kinda show you the output there.

00:35:06.420 --> 00:35:07.370
There we go.

671
00:35:07.370 --> 00:35:09.150
That's typically what you'll see.

672
00:35:09.150 --> 00:35:12.186
You'll notice this is giving

this is everything about this network.

674

We're seeing IP addresses and also actual

675
00:35:19.704 --> 00:35:24.128
get IP addresses for the host names

Right here through dig, very,

that's why Wes got a little

>> Is maybe they're regulating it so

Unexplained reasons,

yeah that's a lot of information

that information you could definitely
stage something like a DNS stage attack or

00:36:13.480 --> 00:36:15.560

00:36:15.560 --> 00:36:16.748
All right, great information, man.

695
00:36:16.748 --> 00:36:18.860
And I know you got a couple left for

696
00:36:18.860 --> 00:36:20.975
>> Yeah, I'm gonna shotgun
them out here real quick for

00:36:20.975 --> 00:36:22.527
us just so we can get it in this episode.

698
00:36:22.527 --> 00:36:24.207
Because it's not gonna fit anywhere else,
and

699
00:36:24.207 --> 00:36:26.460
it goes perfectly with
what we're talking about.

700
00:36:26.460 --> 00:36:29.840
Nmap actually will do some DNS work for
you.

701
00:36:29.840 --> 00:36:35.520
It works with your resolver cache,
it'll work with your own DNS servers.

702
00:36:35.520 --> 00:36:39.310
It always does a DNS reverse lookup
from any host that it finds and

703
00:36:39.310 --> 00:36:43.650
starts to scan, does that to verify its IP
to all the things that we want it to do,

704
00:36:43.650 --> 00:36:45.830
give me that information
about this machine.

705
00:36:45.830 --> 00:36:47.190
So, I just wanted you to be aware of that.

706
00:36:47.190 --> 00:36:51.460
Let's see here, does DNS on every lookup,

707
00:36:51.460 --> 00:36:56.550
we can turn discovery off,
where it does like a ping scan, and

708
00:36:56.550 --> 00:37:02.530
then it'll do resolution for only the IPs
that it actually finds in the scan.

709
00:37:02.530 --> 00:37:04.000
What else do we want to know?

710
00:37:04.000 --> 00:37:07.580
There are four options for
controlling resolution.

711
00:37:07.580 --> 00:37:12.170
A dash N, so
if you just have N map dash lowercase N,

712
00:37:12.170 --> 00:37:14.478
actually let's jump to the screen so
you can see it a little easier.

713
00:37:14.478 --> 00:37:18.030
Zoom in down there.

714
00:37:18.030 --> 00:37:21.090
So I did nmap -n like so.

715
00:37:21.090 --> 00:37:24.320
What that does is this
says do no DNS resolution.

716
00:37:24.320 --> 00:37:26.840
And it does that to it'll
speed things up immensely.

717
00:37:26.840 --> 00:37:28.800
So if I'm doing a large scan,

718
00:37:28.800 --> 00:37:32.980
maybe I don't wanna do DNA resolution
just because I know it's good IPs, right?

719
00:37:32.980 --> 00:37:34.830
I just want it to do the scan.

720
00:37:34.830 --> 00:37:36.530
Leave DNS resolution out of it,

721
00:37:36.530 --> 00:37:40.250
that -n will help you with that turn,
that resolution off.

722
00:37:40.250 --> 00:37:47.820
If we do -R like so, a capital R, It will
do DNS resolution for all targets, right?

723
00:37:47.820 --> 00:37:51.190
It will make sure that it does do
DNS resolution for the targets.

724
00:37:51.190 --> 00:37:54.230
So if for whatever reason maybe
you've changed the profile,

725
00:37:54.230 --> 00:37:57.440
to change the default way in which
it's working, maybe using zenmap,

726
00:37:57.440 --> 00:37:59.780
something to that effect,
you can have a dash r, get that back.

727
00:38:01.380 --> 00:38:02.190
What else do we have?

728
00:38:02.190 --> 00:38:04.100
Use your own system DNS.

729
00:38:04.100 --> 00:38:10.820
You can do that by just
saying --system-dns, like so.

730
00:38:10.820 --> 00:38:14.580
And then, whatever your DNS name,
maybe it's 192.168.

731
00:38:14.580 --> 00:38:17.020
Whatever it is, throw that on there.

732
00:38:17.020 --> 00:38:20.680
Well, the last one is
choose your DNS server.

733
00:38:20.680 --> 00:38:22.990
So if I,
kind of like what we're doing with dig,

734
00:38:22.990 --> 00:38:27.140
where we were specifying what
dns server we wanted to use.

735
00:38:27.140 --> 00:38:31.550
I can do DNS-servers, and then say

736
00:38:32.640 --> 00:38:36.540
this server and next server, and just give
it a list of servers that I wanted to use.

737
00:38:36.540 --> 00:38:38.100
Why wouldn't I want to do that?

738
00:38:38.100 --> 00:38:41.670
Well one DNS server might illicit
more information than another, or

739
00:38:41.670 --> 00:38:43.050
just different information.

740
00:38:43.050 --> 00:38:46.740
So sometimes you want to pin point
what DNS servers you're using and

741
00:38:46.740 --> 00:38:53.000
inmap is capable of doing a lot of good
DNS searching and resolution for user.

742
00:38:53.000 --> 00:38:56.870
That being said,
I know it's a lot to digest,

743
00:38:56.870 --> 00:38:59.710
it's a lot to work with but
you do want to verify those hosts.

744
00:38:59.710 --> 00:39:03.560
You do want to make sure you're scanning
stuff that you actually want to scan.

745
00:39:03.560 --> 00:39:04.380
There you go.

746
00:39:04.380 --> 00:39:04.930
>> All right Dan.

747
00:39:04.930 --> 00:39:06.450
Thank you for that foundational knowledge.

748
00:39:06.450 --> 00:39:08.540
I know it's a lot of information but
you know what,

749
00:39:08.540 --> 00:39:11.100
when you start any new
technology you need to learn it.

750
00:39:11.100 --> 00:39:12.160
You need a good foundation.

751
00:39:12.160 --> 00:39:15.710
But we're gonna take this time to
ahead and sign out here at ITProTV.

752
00:39:15.710 --> 00:39:17.130
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

753
00:39:17.130 --> 00:39:17.960
>> I'm Daniel Lowrie.

754
00:39:17.960 --> 00:39:19.028
>> And we'll see you next time.

755
00:39:19.028 --> 00:39:27.900
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Dan dive into host discovery with Nmap. They look at performing a ping sweep scan and explain what encompasses a default ping. They demonstrate scans that use ICMP ECHOs , ARP and TCP ACKs and SYN request packets to generate the information.
episodes.title: Host Discovery

Host discovery is what

00:01:51.610 --> 00:01:56.430
Well a, host discovery is just that we're
discovering a host, nodes, computers,

37

machines, devices that our networked and
are alive and kicking.

38

We want to find out what those are and

nmap, or at least one of the major

One of the major basic

That's what we're talking about so

Ping or

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Dan continue their discussion on host discovery with Nmap.  They look at how to find hidden hosts through SYN pings. They also demonstrate how to use SYN pings to discover hidden hosts that are firewalled.
episodes.title: Host Discovery Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

[MUSIC]

We were nowhere near done

And eventually we will get to actual port

Because it can be a little confusing,

These things tend to make

as I have definitely come to find out.

[LAUGH] Normally I run as root for

So it's a bad practice, don't do that.

[LAUGH] With that being said,
let's continue with host discovery, and

26
00:01:25.131 --> 00:01:29.070
taking a look at, well basically,

00:01:29.070 --> 00:01:33.807
This is something that happens a lot,

if you can ping my computer

You kinda see that it's there and

Sometimes it is and that's why we
allowed it during those times, but

31

a lot of times it's not.

32
00:01:45.643 --> 00:01:50.120
And a lot of people they start shutting

33

If I'm a network administrator,
I'm a sysadmin,

I'm somebody that I need to see

35
00:01:57.028 --> 00:01:58.719
And I wanna check hosts,

36
00:01:58.719 --> 00:02:03.572
make sure that what I'm seeing is what

Gotta love rogue access points and

People plugging in laptops to points that

This is the kind of

And by looking for these things,
by discovering hey I got

I've got some rogue hosts on my network.

We can start to mitigate any security

So that's what we wanna
be on the look out for.

>> You know Dan, you said rogue

these have got to be

I was thinking about something recently,

00:02:42.590 --> 00:02:47.290
And you fire up a mobile device, you fire

all of a sudden in the devices that

51
00:02:51.414 --> 00:02:54.859
You didn't realize it that the wifi's

52
00:02:54.859 --> 00:02:57.330
now people have a,
pretty much an open access point.

53
00:02:57.330 --> 00:03:01.215
So I can see where finding hosts

54
00:03:01.215 --> 00:03:04.464
But Dan I have a feeling you're gonna show
us what happens when those hosts aren't so

00:03:04.464 --> 00:03:05.362
easy to find, right?

56
00:03:05.362 --> 00:03:09.800
>> That's right, we do have
hosts that we will tend to hide.

00:03:09.800 --> 00:03:11.930
But if I want to do a thorough scan,

00:03:11.930 --> 00:03:14.420
I want to make sure that

So I want to kinda put my black hat on for

00:03:32.960 --> 00:03:36.330
But because I'm better as a hacker,

00:03:36.330 --> 00:03:38.770
I'm a very good hacker,

So that's the kind of role

We're going to play

69
00:03:46.730 --> 00:03:51.170

72
00:03:57.030 --> 00:04:01.140
So while I play a black hat I can

74
00:04:04.390 --> 00:04:07.700
I found it through these various means,

75
00:04:07.700 --> 00:04:08.730
And the other way around,

76
00:04:08.730 --> 00:04:12.360
if I wanted to stop hackers,
what would I do, how would I work that?

77
00:04:12.360 --> 00:04:13.645
So that's what we're looking at today.

78
00:04:13.645 --> 00:04:17.882
And we're gonna start off, so
we talk about firewalled machines, right?

79
00:04:17.882 --> 00:04:22.696
So what happens when I send a ping,
if I ping a machine who uses the ICMP

80
00:04:22.696 --> 00:04:26.277
protocol to send an echo and

81
00:04:26.277 --> 00:04:28.435
That's basically what's going on here.

00:04:28.435 --> 00:04:33.210
And when that reply comes back I know that

00:04:33.210 --> 00:04:35.680

84
00:04:35.680 --> 00:04:37.720
It's alive, it's up, cuz it responded.

85
00:04:37.720 --> 00:04:40.550
And I have a full connection

86
00:04:40.550 --> 00:04:44.800
And that's a good thing,
that's why it's such a nice utility, ping.

87
00:04:44.800 --> 00:04:49.560
But if I'm blocking it, if I'm firewalling

88
00:04:49.560 --> 00:04:52.930
How do I as an NMAP user,
if I'm trying to scan a network

89
00:04:52.930 --> 00:04:56.948
where things might be being blocked,
how do I discover those hosts?

90
00:04:56.948 --> 00:04:59.750
So let's start off with one of the basic
ways in which we'll do this, and

91
00:04:59.750 --> 00:05:02.790
I say basic, it's got a lot of things

92
00:05:02.790 --> 00:05:06.290
And it is the SYN ping as we'll call it.

93
00:05:06.290 --> 00:05:10.400
I think the NMAP documentation even

94
00:05:10.400 --> 00:05:12.210
You're like sin as in sinful?

95
00:05:12.210 --> 00:05:16.720
No, we're not sinful like that,
S Y N, not S I N, right.

96
00:05:16.720 --> 00:05:22.484
The SYN flag that begins ATCP handshake,
right, the three way handshake.

97
00:05:22.484 --> 00:05:25.539
And you're thinking to yourself,
I remember them talking about that,

98

I'm looking for machines and

547
00:30:15.940 --> 00:30:20.570
I know the Windows firewall
blocks that PS scan by default.

548
00:30:20.570 --> 00:30:21.780
So what am I gonna do, right?

549
00:30:21.780 --> 00:30:22.930
We're gonna use our work-around.

550
00:30:22.930 --> 00:30:24.820
We're gonna throw different ports at it.

551
00:30:24.820 --> 00:30:28.400
Now the thing was about this,
is, I thought well maybe

552
00:30:28.400 --> 00:30:30.710
port 80 obviously isn't working,
it doesn't have a web server or

553
00:30:30.710 --> 00:30:34.640
anything running, that port's closed, and
the firewall is dropping the packets.

554
00:30:34.640 --> 00:30:35.640
That's the problem.

555
00:30:35.640 --> 00:30:39.010
The firewall is not
allowing the packet to go.

556
00:30:39.010 --> 00:30:41.630
I'm a port that's not open,
here's a reset.

557
00:30:41.630 --> 00:30:44.950
Even if the port is closed and
I should get that reset, or

558
00:30:44.950 --> 00:30:48.490
if it's open the firewall is saying nein,
no, don't do that.

559
00:30:48.490 --> 00:30:50.680
I'm just going to drop
the packets on floor,

560
00:30:50.680 --> 00:30:52.670
I'm not going to elicit any response.

561
00:30:52.670 --> 00:30:54.870
And that's why that's not showing as up.

562
00:30:54.870 --> 00:30:56.180
Firewall is doing a great job.

563
00:30:56.180 --> 00:30:57.540
That's what we want.

564
00:30:57.540 --> 00:31:00.080
So how do we get around that,
how do we do that?

565
00:31:00.080 --> 00:31:04.409
The answer I found was to scan all 6,550,
right?

566
00:31:04.409 --> 00:31:07.510
65,000, I'm sorry, 65,535 ports.

567
00:31:07.510 --> 00:31:13.710
Now I will spare you the time
that it takes to do that,

568
00:31:13.710 --> 00:31:18.000
even on a single machine,
let alone a range of machines.

569
00:31:18.000 --> 00:31:19.820
I've already kind of pre-baked this for
us so

570
00:31:19.820 --> 00:31:21.810
that we can see it without
having to wait for it.

571
00:31:21.810 --> 00:31:24.020
Put that turkey in the oven,
just pull up the cooked one right out.

572
00:31:24.020 --> 00:31:24.680
All right, so

573
00:31:24.680 --> 00:31:28.280
yeah I've got this, well you know what
actually like I said I saved the scan.

574
00:31:28.280 --> 00:31:30.570
I was a smart person, precook this.

575
00:31:30.570 --> 00:31:32.000
Here it is right here.

576
00:31:32.000 --> 00:31:33.220
So here is the command.

577
00:31:34.580 --> 00:31:39.740
Sudo elevated privileges nmap sn,
we only wanna do ping type scans.

578
00:31:39.740 --> 00:31:43.610
And there's my ps for my sin ping,
and then I gave it the port range.

579
00:31:43.610 --> 00:31:47.710
Remember I showed you how
to do the port range.

580
00:31:47.710 --> 00:31:50.709
One through 65,535,
wow that's a lot of ports.

581
00:31:50.709 --> 00:31:55.496
You started, and as I kicked it off, and
you'll notice it's the same exact thing,

582
00:31:55.496 --> 00:31:57.397
I did a range, 134 to 137.

583
00:31:57.397 --> 00:31:59.802
And you'll notice I got
some weird results,

584
00:31:59.802 --> 00:32:02.610
it didn't really like what
was going on [LAUGH] here.

585
00:32:02.610 --> 00:32:06.470
Probably because of the massive
amount of activity that was going on.

586
00:32:06.470 --> 00:32:10.980
Gave me some, okay, if you really want to
see all these errors that we're getting,

587
00:32:10.980 --> 00:32:15.860
you can add this -d2 option but obviously,
I wasn't too enthused about that.

588
00:32:15.860 --> 00:32:19.630
Then it gave me some countdown,
how long it was left before it was done.

589
00:32:19.630 --> 00:32:25.070
Then it completed the scan and
found two hosts up, right?

590
00:32:25.070 --> 00:32:25.890
That's good, right?

591
00:32:25.890 --> 00:32:27.290
There it is, right there.

592
00:32:27.290 --> 00:32:32.520
Bing, host is up, nice.

593
00:32:32.520 --> 00:32:33.550
It found a scan.

594
00:32:33.550 --> 00:32:35.400
But which port did it find it on?

595
00:32:35.400 --> 00:32:36.640
I don't know, right?

596
00:32:36.640 --> 00:32:38.470
I didn't get to see that part.

597
00:32:38.470 --> 00:32:39.730
It really wasn't part of the output.

598
00:32:40.870 --> 00:32:43.240
But being a seasoned veteran as I am,

599
00:32:43.240 --> 00:32:46.110
I know some software that
will help us out with that.

600
00:32:46.110 --> 00:32:48.500
That's our good old friend Wireshark.

601
00:32:48.500 --> 00:32:50.560
So what I did was before
I fired off the scan,

602
00:32:50.560 --> 00:32:56.430
I started sniffing my network
to see what the activity was.

603
00:32:56.430 --> 00:32:58.180
I can actually see that stuff.

604
00:32:58.180 --> 00:33:01.250
So what I did was, again,
already had this stuff pre-baked for us.

605
00:33:01.250 --> 00:33:06.144
I had my Wireshark output right here and
I've sorted it by source

606
00:33:06.144 --> 00:33:10.688
IP that would go descending
instead of ascending, right?

607
00:33:10.688 --> 00:33:14.566
So instead of starting from one and going
up, it starts from the highest number, and

608
00:33:14.566 --> 00:33:15.777
goes down to one, right?

609
00:33:15.777 --> 00:33:17.080
So that's where I'm looking at.

610
00:33:17.080 --> 00:33:21.450
Here, we see a lot of ARP requests, and
as you can see, that's what it's doing,

611
00:33:21.450 --> 00:33:22.670
it's trying to ARP out.

612
00:33:22.670 --> 00:33:25.762
ARP is a good thing and
that's why we can find so

613
00:33:25.762 --> 00:33:30.678
many things, but once we get past our
ARP information, which is almost,

614
00:33:30.678 --> 00:33:34.035
there we go,
here's our actual from the source.

615
00:33:34.035 --> 00:33:39.982
So it's coming from 192.168.219.136,
that's my Windows 10 machine.

616
00:33:39.982 --> 00:33:41.721
And where's it going to?

617
00:33:41.721 --> 00:33:44.567
The destination 192.168.219.1.

618
00:33:44.567 --> 00:33:45.905
That's me, that's my attack machine.

619
00:33:45.905 --> 00:33:48.227
That means it actually
made a response back.

620
00:33:48.227 --> 00:33:48.958
And what was it?

621
00:33:48.958 --> 00:33:52.456
It was a TCP protocol on port 7680,

622
00:33:52.456 --> 00:33:57.120
back to the originating
port which was 39526.

623
00:33:57.120 --> 00:33:58.092
And what is it?

624
00:33:58.092 --> 00:34:00.516
A synac, right?

625
00:34:00.516 --> 00:34:01.500
A synac.

626
00:34:01.500 --> 00:34:02.640
Well, excellent.

627
00:34:02.640 --> 00:34:07.426
That means the port is actually open and
able to make connections, and

628
00:34:07.426 --> 00:34:08.540
it sent that back to me.

629
00:34:08.540 --> 00:34:13.000
So I'm sure if we looked back through, we
would see the RST that I sent back saying,

630
00:34:13.000 --> 00:34:15.370
no, no, we're good,
thank you for your response.

631
00:34:15.370 --> 00:34:20.749
I now know that port 7680 is open on that
machine and that's why it found it open.

632
00:34:20.749 --> 00:34:25.314
So if I wanted to, and I said, I know
I got a bunch of Windows 10 machines,

633
00:34:25.314 --> 00:34:29.229
I wanna scan, I'd probably do
that PS with 7680 as my port,

634
00:34:29.229 --> 00:34:31.494
instead of the default as port 80.

635
00:34:31.494 --> 00:34:33.530
Let's see if that actually works.

636
00:34:33.530 --> 00:34:35.550
Let me shrink this down.

637
00:34:35.550 --> 00:34:38.260
We'll go back over here, and
we'll say, let's see here.

638
00:34:39.500 --> 00:34:44.580
I will just add the port
7680 to my sim ping,

639
00:34:44.580 --> 00:34:48.670
hit Return, asks for
my password, of course.

640
00:34:51.010 --> 00:34:51.870
There we go.

641
00:34:51.870 --> 00:34:55.080
We see two hosts are up,
that ping is actually working, so

642
00:34:55.080 --> 00:35:00.710
now I have an effective canned
response for Windows 10 machines.

643
00:35:00.710 --> 00:35:04.830
I know this will work if I've got a whole
host of Windows 10 machines that,

644
00:35:04.830 --> 00:35:08.390
even though they're blocking the standard
ping and even that sim ping to port 80,

645
00:35:08.390 --> 00:35:10.480
I can use that port to get around this.

646
00:35:10.480 --> 00:35:13.570
Now you're starting to see
the importance of doing this and

647
00:35:13.570 --> 00:35:18.200
understanding what's happening under the
hood so that we can get around firewalls.

648
00:35:18.200 --> 00:35:21.750
>> I was gonna say great job, that's very
crafty there, finding that hidden host.

649
00:35:21.750 --> 00:35:24.550
I thought the blinders were
gonna be on there for a second.

650
00:35:24.550 --> 00:35:27.491
Dan, it does look like we are coming
to the end of another episode, so

651
00:35:27.491 --> 00:35:29.536
before we do go,
do you have any parting words?

652
00:35:29.536 --> 00:35:32.851
>> No, other than we're nowhere near done,
right?

653
00:35:32.851 --> 00:35:36.230
Host discovery, well, we're about
halfway through it, should I say.

654
00:35:36.230 --> 00:35:38.880
We got some other tricks
in our toolkit just in case

655
00:35:38.880 --> 00:35:42.420
we get some crafty admins out there that
go, I see what you did there, right?

656
00:35:42.420 --> 00:35:46.950
We're always playing back and forth with
the sys admins versus the bad guys, and

657
00:35:46.950 --> 00:35:50.630
we have to play both sides so that we
can effectively secure our network.

658
00:35:50.630 --> 00:35:53.542
So, we're gonna take a look at some
more stuff in an upcoming episode.

659
00:35:53.542 --> 00:35:55.760
>> All right, well, I look forward
to seeing you in part three and

660
00:35:55.760 --> 00:35:58.080
we look forward to having you there
too but we're gonna go ahead and

661
00:35:58.080 --> 00:35:59.360
take this time to sign out.

662
00:35:59.360 --> 00:36:00.730
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

663
00:36:00.730 --> 00:36:01.349
>> I'm Daniel Lowrie.

664
00:36:01.349 --> 00:36:02.742
>> And we'll see you next time.

665
00:36:02.742 --> 00:36:09.182
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Dan continue their discussion on host discovery with Nmap. They venture away from using TCP and take a look at using UDP pings. They will explore some of the various ICMP ping types like echo requests, time stamp requests, address mask replies as well as ARP pings.
episodes.title: Host Discovery Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:10.008
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.088 --> 00:00:16.320
Welcome back to another exciting episode
here at ITProTV, I'm your host Wes Bryan.

3
00:00:16.320 --> 00:00:19.320
And in today's episode we're
moving through our series on Nmap.

4
00:00:19.320 --> 00:00:21.070
And more specifically,

5
00:00:21.070 --> 00:00:24.270
we're continuing along with
the novel that is host discovery.

6
00:00:24.270 --> 00:00:26.470
We've got a couple of
parts under our belts and

7
00:00:26.470 --> 00:00:27.620
we're coming back with a part three.

8
00:00:27.620 --> 00:00:30.590
And to help lend his expertise is
none other than Mr. Dan Lowrie.

9
00:00:30.590 --> 00:00:31.278
Dan, how're you doing today, sir?

10
00:00:31.278 --> 00:00:34.338
I'm doing fantastic, Wes,
thanks so much for having me back.

11
00:00:34.338 --> 00:00:35.862
Because you're right,

12
00:00:35.862 --> 00:00:40.298
this is turning into quite the extensive
volume that is host discovery.

13
00:00:40.298 --> 00:00:45.558
But it's good stuff, it's definitely
going to help you as an Nmap user.

14
00:00:45.558 --> 00:00:49.328
As someone who's gonna be doing security
testing against your own systems,

15
00:00:49.328 --> 00:00:52.290
maybe even becoming that
penetration tester one day.

16
00:00:52.290 --> 00:00:54.080
You don't wanna say, yeah I've used Nmap,

17
00:00:54.080 --> 00:00:58.040
and all you've really done is thrown
a couple of easy scans at machines before.

18
00:00:58.040 --> 00:01:01.690
That's not really using Nmap,
even thought that is using Nmap.

19
00:01:01.690 --> 00:01:06.960
We want a much wider breadth to our
knowledge when it comes to Nmap.

20
00:01:06.960 --> 00:01:11.108
So we've been working our way through host
discovery, [SOUND] and it is lengthy.

21
00:01:11.108 --> 00:01:14.334
We have gotten to the part now where,
let's see here,

22
00:01:14.334 --> 00:01:18.290
we've talked about getting
around firewalled computers.

23
00:01:18.290 --> 00:01:21.490
Pinging machines, I wanna see
what machines are on my network.

24
00:01:21.490 --> 00:01:24.530
And when that doesn't work
because of firewalling ping, or

25
00:01:24.530 --> 00:01:26.600
disabling ping, what do I do?

26
00:01:26.600 --> 00:01:29.710
Well we've got things around that,
we looked at the -ps, or

27
00:01:29.710 --> 00:01:35.350
the sin ping utility built into
Nmap as well, and that was great.

28
00:01:35.350 --> 00:01:36.278
That was a wonderful little tool.

29
00:01:36.278 --> 00:01:40.998
We actually were able to
circumvent a Windows 10 firewall.

30
00:01:40.998 --> 00:01:44.877
We got right around that bad boy,
even though it was blocking us before, and

31
00:01:44.877 --> 00:01:47.360
we were able to find machines using that.

32
00:01:47.360 --> 00:01:52.820
But now we need to take a look at its
brother, and that is the ACK scan.

33
00:01:52.820 --> 00:01:55.390
And that's, you're thinking, yeah I've
hear of ACK, well yeah that's because

34
00:01:55.390 --> 00:02:00.340
we've talked about ACK and SYN, and
SYN-ACK, and all the variations thereof.

35
00:02:00.340 --> 00:02:03.837
So that's where we're
gonna start in with today,

36
00:02:03.837 --> 00:02:07.428
is with using the PA, or
the ACK ping inside of Nmap.

37
00:02:07.428 --> 00:02:11.368
>> Now Dan, I know a little about
the three way handshake before.

38
00:02:11.368 --> 00:02:14.408
And I can understand why you're
using a synchronization request.

39
00:02:14.408 --> 00:02:18.043
You're trying to, is that machine out
there and even if it doesn't give you that

40
00:02:18.043 --> 00:02:21.660
SYN-ACK packet back it's going to give
me some errors, says hey I'm closed.

41
00:02:21.660 --> 00:02:25.340
Now why in the world would we use
ACK when that's the third and

42
00:02:25.340 --> 00:02:29.580
final part of a handshake that
hasn't really even gone on yet.

43
00:02:29.580 --> 00:02:31.630
>> Yeah, I know it sounds weird.

44
00:02:31.630 --> 00:02:38.010
You're like, we're basically forgetting
the first portion of a TCP connection.

45
00:02:38.010 --> 00:02:39.570
How the heck does that even work?

46
00:02:39.570 --> 00:02:44.890
Well the good thing is,
is that Nmap as a system level utility

47
00:02:44.890 --> 00:02:48.350
is able to control the flags.

48
00:02:48.350 --> 00:02:49.990
We can turn on the SYN flag.

49
00:02:49.990 --> 00:02:52.640
Well, if we can turn on the SYN flag,
we can also turn on the ACK flag.

50
00:02:52.640 --> 00:02:55.560
And that goes back to Wes's question,
why would we do that?

51
00:02:55.560 --> 00:02:56.810
Why wouldn't we start with ping?

52
00:02:56.810 --> 00:03:03.530
And the great answer to that question is,
why don't we start with SYN, the SYN ping?

53
00:03:03.530 --> 00:03:04.820
What if SYNs being blocked?

54
00:03:04.820 --> 00:03:09.780
What if someone gets wise, and says,
well I understand Nmap, by default,

55
00:03:09.780 --> 00:03:12.820
if you use that PS argument against it.

56
00:03:12.820 --> 00:03:17.210
It will just send a SYN flag to port 80,
I'll block port 80.

57
00:03:17.210 --> 00:03:21.410
Heck, I might even block all
the ports from that SYN request

58
00:03:21.410 --> 00:03:23.040
you little rascal, you.

59
00:03:23.040 --> 00:03:24.510
And now what do you do?

60
00:03:24.510 --> 00:03:27.980
And that's when we would enter
into using the ACK request,

61
00:03:27.980 --> 00:03:30.300
because you probably aren't blocking that.

62
00:03:30.300 --> 00:03:33.880
Of course you could, but
you've gotta remember most people,

63
00:03:33.880 --> 00:03:36.740
they probably aren't thinking
of this right out of the gate.

64
00:03:36.740 --> 00:03:38.210
They just think I just need to block ping.

65
00:03:38.210 --> 00:03:39.900
And that's why PS works.

66
00:03:39.900 --> 00:03:45.260
And if they get bit by that bug, they go,
well I'll block SYN, and that will work.

67
00:03:45.260 --> 00:03:46.450
Well, guess what?

68
00:03:46.450 --> 00:03:48.210
Got another way around your
little firewall there, and

69
00:03:48.210 --> 00:03:50.070
that is using our ACK packet.

70
00:03:50.070 --> 00:03:50.880
Now, how does this work?

71
00:03:50.880 --> 00:03:56.810
It's very simple, it's in the very
same vein of the SYN ping.

72
00:03:56.810 --> 00:04:01.470
Our ACK ping is gonna send an ACK
packet to port 80, by default.

73
00:04:01.470 --> 00:04:06.020
Again, we can use all our
standard malformation.

74
00:04:06.020 --> 00:04:08.950
So if we wanted to do something
like change the port from

75
00:04:08.950 --> 00:04:13.280
port 80 to port 443 or any other port for
that matter, just add it on the end there.

76
00:04:13.280 --> 00:04:17.180
If we wanna do a range of ports,
do the hyphen with those beginning and

77
00:04:17.180 --> 00:04:18.780
ending ports that you wanna use.

78
00:04:18.780 --> 00:04:20.780
It works there as well, same kind of idea.

79
00:04:20.780 --> 00:04:22.630
If you wanna comment the limits,

80
00:04:22.630 --> 00:04:26.130
specific ports out of the range of ports,
you can do that.

81
00:04:26.130 --> 00:04:28.420
So all the good stuff we learned
in the previous episode,

82
00:04:28.420 --> 00:04:30.750
that works here just as well.

83
00:04:30.750 --> 00:04:34.380
And that's basically all you need to know
about it, for all intents and purposes.

84
00:04:34.380 --> 00:04:38.070
So very similar to the sin but
the difference is,

85
00:04:38.070 --> 00:04:43.600
it's sending that ACK request instead,
the ACK flag instead of the SYN flag.

86
00:04:43.600 --> 00:04:45.300
So let's take a look at my computer.

87
00:04:46.330 --> 00:04:49.390
We don't wanna just talk about these
things, I wanna show you this stuff guys.

88
00:04:49.390 --> 00:04:51.210
So let's see here.

89
00:04:51.210 --> 00:04:52.990
For testing purposes,
where are we at here?

90
00:04:52.990 --> 00:04:55.390
I'm gonna follow my notes here so
I make sure I'm on the right page for

91
00:04:55.390 --> 00:04:58.440
you, let's do this.

92
00:04:58.440 --> 00:05:04.308
Let's go to the Metasploitable machine and
let's shut off sin.

93
00:05:04.308 --> 00:05:08.749
Because right now if I do an Nmap,

94
00:05:08.749 --> 00:05:13.508
I sudo nmap -sn- PS and then I say,

95
00:05:13.508 --> 00:05:18.107
I do the -n -v and when I do the,

96
00:05:18.107 --> 00:05:22.248
don't forget my --sendIP.

97
00:05:22.248 --> 00:05:27.552
And then 192.168, if I can hit my dot,

98
00:05:27.552 --> 00:05:31.088
.168.219.135.

99
00:05:31.088 --> 00:05:35.781
That's my Metasploitable e
machine's address, if I hit that,

100
00:05:35.781 --> 00:05:38.180
hit return, put my password in.

101
00:05:39.880 --> 00:05:41.190
And I see, one host up.

102
00:05:41.190 --> 00:05:42.910
Great, that actually worked.

103
00:05:42.910 --> 00:05:45.820
That's because I don't have
any fire walling going off.

104
00:05:45.820 --> 00:05:48.270
I'm a smart Nmap user,

105
00:05:48.270 --> 00:05:52.150
I've gotten around any, maybe if I had
a firewall up for that ping request.

00:30:13.680 --> 00:30:18.494
have to enable it, but if you needed to
for whatever reason, it's -pr, right?

565
00:30:18.494 --> 00:30:23.474
So -pr and
that will make sure it uses arp-scanning

566
00:30:23.474 --> 00:30:26.270
instead of echoes or
whatever the case may be.

567
00:30:26.270 --> 00:30:27.690
So use pr for that.

568
00:30:27.690 --> 00:30:29.640
It's great for LANs.

569
00:30:29.640 --> 00:30:32.620
Super fast,
really picks up a lot of information.

570
00:30:32.620 --> 00:30:34.090
It's very reliable.

571
00:30:34.090 --> 00:30:36.560
>> You know, I could see why Art would

572
00:30:36.560 --> 00:30:39.290
be beneficial definitely
in trying to find out host.

573
00:30:39.290 --> 00:30:42.250
Cause any time I want to get somebody's
attention in the mall the first

574
00:30:42.250 --> 00:30:44.970
thing I do is jump up on the table,
and scream at the top of my lungs and

575
00:30:44.970 --> 00:30:46.120
I usually get some kind of response.

576
00:30:46.120 --> 00:30:49.940
Everybody in the courtyard looks back
at me And our is broadcast right.

577
00:30:49.940 --> 00:30:52.410
So if everybody on
the network should respond.

578
00:30:52.410 --> 00:30:53.970
Great stuff there Dan.

579
00:30:53.970 --> 00:30:55.710
I think we've got a couple
more though right?

580
00:30:55.710 --> 00:30:58.660
>> Yeah just two more for
your education purposes.

581
00:30:58.660 --> 00:31:03.390
And this is dash P Y and dash P O,
these are both new scans.

582
00:31:03.390 --> 00:31:09.450
I'm just gonna let the nmap manual
page here do the talking there.

583
00:31:09.450 --> 00:31:15.510
There we go, PY is a portless or
SCTP INIT ping scan.

584
00:31:15.510 --> 00:31:18.140
This is new territory for even myself,

585
00:31:18.140 --> 00:31:23.870
this is I think With the newest
version of Nmap or just prior.

586
00:31:23.870 --> 00:31:29.130
I haven't had any real experience with it,
other than it works very similar,

587
00:31:29.130 --> 00:31:33.780
just differently, but very similarly
to the other scans we've done so far.

588
00:31:33.780 --> 00:31:36.350
>> Is this one that you'd have
to be a privileged user Dan, or

589
00:31:36.350 --> 00:31:39.260
can you be a non-privileged user,
how would you have to run this?

590
00:31:39.260 --> 00:31:40.380
>> Yeah, great question,

591
00:31:40.380 --> 00:31:45.210
and you absolutely have to be a privileged
user to run this type of scan.

592
00:31:45.210 --> 00:31:51.800
And the next one, which is This one
right here POP, the IP Protocol Ping.

593
00:31:51.800 --> 00:31:56.640
So, it gives you a certain levels of,
again another one that's new to me

594
00:31:56.640 --> 00:31:59.510
on how to use it but
it's right there on the documentation.

595
00:31:59.510 --> 00:32:01.900
So, you got to look at
words very similarly and

596
00:32:01.900 --> 00:32:06.110
again you just go to the dash PO
all the port options actually work.

597
00:32:06.110 --> 00:32:09.140
I think this is the only one that is
different that's give you a range

598
00:32:09.140 --> 00:32:11.780
of 1 to 255 these different
types of protocol options

599
00:32:11.780 --> 00:32:16.350
doesn't really get into
great detail in here.

600
00:32:16.350 --> 00:32:21.490
You have ICMP, protocol one,
IGMP which is protocol two,

601
00:32:21.490 --> 00:32:26.050
and IPNIP which is protocol four, so
you use one of these types of things.

602
00:32:26.050 --> 00:32:27.110
And it's just, again,

603
00:32:27.110 --> 00:32:30.750
trying to elicit some sort of
response From the target machine.

604
00:32:30.750 --> 00:32:34.460
So you can just throw every
one of these scans at it.

605
00:32:34.460 --> 00:32:38.370
Have ten different scans running
simultaneously if you want.

606
00:32:38.370 --> 00:32:41.670
Other than it'll take awhile
it's not going to hurt anything.

607
00:32:41.670 --> 00:32:44.990
So use them all make sure
that you play with them,

608
00:32:44.990 --> 00:32:46.450
if one doesn't work try the other one.

609
00:32:46.450 --> 00:32:47.950
If that doesn't work, try another one.

610
00:32:47.950 --> 00:32:50.390
If you're trying to fire wall things off,

611
00:32:50.390 --> 00:32:53.320
use these scans to see if you can
get around your fire wall, and

612
00:32:53.320 --> 00:32:56.860
then go back to the drawing board
as far as your fire wall goes.

613
00:32:56.860 --> 00:32:59.070
Host discovery, there it is.

614
00:32:59.070 --> 00:33:00.140
>> Dan thank you so much.

615
00:33:00.140 --> 00:33:02.370
It's been a long journey that
we've been taken through.

616
00:33:02.370 --> 00:33:04.190
Host discovery and
the journey's long, why?

617
00:33:04.190 --> 00:33:06.730
Because end math is very powerful and
there's a lot of options.

618
00:33:06.730 --> 00:33:09.240
So take Dan's advice Use different scans.

619
00:33:09.240 --> 00:33:11.910
If you don't get the results you
want make sure you are in sudo or

620
00:33:11.910 --> 00:33:13.360
you're a non sudo user.

621
00:33:13.360 --> 00:33:15.810
Dan, I do see that we are coming
to the end of another episode.

622
00:33:15.810 --> 00:33:18.040
But before we leave do you
have any words of wisdom?

623
00:33:18.040 --> 00:33:22.360
>> Yeah, just again do not scan
machines that you do not own.

624
00:33:22.360 --> 00:33:23.580
Pinging is one thing.

625
00:33:23.580 --> 00:33:28.190
Make sure you use that sn if you want
to just scan machines that are not

626
00:33:28.190 --> 00:33:29.830
within your territory so

627
00:33:29.830 --> 00:33:33.550
to speak, that way it doesn't actually
do any kind of port scanning yet.

628
00:33:33.550 --> 00:33:34.610
We'll get to port scanning,

629
00:33:34.610 --> 00:33:36.980
though it's actually coming up
in our next couple of episodes.

630
00:33:36.980 --> 00:33:39.640
>> Well thank you for being here Dan,
and thank you guys for watching, but

631
00:33:39.640 --> 00:33:41.480
we're gonna go ahead and
take this time to sign out.

632
00:33:41.480 --> 00:33:43.550
I've been your host Wes Bryan
>> I'm Daniel Lowry.

633
00:33:43.550 --> 00:33:45.913
>> And we'll see you next time.

634
00:33:45.913 --> 00:33:53.420
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Dan discuss the various states of TCP/IP ports. They demonstrate the output that can be received within Nmap when a port scan is performed. They cover open, closed, filtered, unfiltered, open/filtered and finally the closed/filtered state.
episodes.title: Port States
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.956 --> 00:00:15.250
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.250 --> 00:00:18.880
I'm your host Wes Bryan, and in today's
episode, we're moving through, or

4
00:00:18.880 --> 00:00:22.020
should I say continuing
through our nmap's here.

5
00:00:22.020 --> 00:00:24.080
We got none other than in
the studio today then Mr.

6
00:00:24.080 --> 00:00:25.630
Dan Lowrie, Dan how you doing sir?

7
00:00:25.630 --> 00:00:28.360
>> Man, I am doing fantastic,
I am so glad to be here,

8
00:00:28.360 --> 00:00:30.760
talking about nmap again with you guys.

9
00:00:30.760 --> 00:00:32.750
And guess what, we're, we're ever so

10
00:00:32.750 --> 00:00:37.080
much closer to actually doing some port
scans and seeing what happens there.

11
00:00:37.080 --> 00:00:42.210
But we got this one episode right
here that we need to have a sit down,

12
00:00:42.210 --> 00:00:44.630
pop a squat, sit by the fire and

13
00:00:44.630 --> 00:00:48.230
understand some things before we
can actually get to that area.

14
00:00:48.230 --> 00:00:51.070
And what I'm talking about is port states.

15
00:00:51.070 --> 00:00:54.790
If I don't know what-,
let me put it this way.

16
00:00:54.790 --> 00:00:59.810
If I run an Nmap scan against a target or
a multitude of targets, and

17
00:00:59.810 --> 00:01:05.425
it returns results to me, and I'm unable
to at least have a basic understanding of

18
00:01:05.425 --> 00:01:11.400
A: What has happened when I fired off
that scan, and B: What is the result?

19
00:01:11.400 --> 00:01:16.930
How can I look at these results with any
kind of understanding and knowledge then

20
00:01:16.930 --> 00:01:21.500
I'm gonna have a hard time using that data
to my advantage later on down the road.

21
00:01:21.500 --> 00:01:25.390
Now typically if you're just running
something maybe just a standard security

22
00:01:25.390 --> 00:01:27.550
scan you can do it the easy way and

23
00:01:27.550 --> 00:01:30.180
that is a very common way
in which this is done.

24
00:01:30.180 --> 00:01:32.100
But if we want to have
that deeper understanding,

25
00:01:32.100 --> 00:01:36.380
well then we need to take a look at
the different port states that we might

26
00:01:36.380 --> 00:01:41.770
encounter, that are elicited by the many
different types of scans that we can run.

27
00:01:41.770 --> 00:01:46.820
And then, once we get this under our
belts, we'll be able to more effectively

28
00:01:46.820 --> 00:01:50.730
look at the different types of port scans,
see the output that comes from it, and

29
00:01:50.730 --> 00:01:53.980
deal with that and
digest it as an end user.

30
00:01:53.980 --> 00:01:56.390
Have that data actually work for
us and mean something.

31
00:01:56.390 --> 00:01:58.470
So that's what today's
episode is all about.

32
00:01:58.470 --> 00:02:03.590
We're gonna take a look at the different
port states and what they mean to us.

33
00:02:03.590 --> 00:02:07.480
That being said, let's hit the ground
running, start with the beginning here.

34
00:02:07.480 --> 00:02:11.470
One of the first things I do what you guys
to understand is that when you fire off

35
00:02:11.470 --> 00:02:14.390
an Nmap scan,
if I got it on to my computer here and

36
00:02:14.390 --> 00:02:20.130
I do a good old sudu nmap and
my target IP or whatever target like so.

37
00:02:20.130 --> 00:02:22.670
And I fired it off, what happens?

38
00:02:22.670 --> 00:02:23.960
What does nmap do?

39
00:02:23.960 --> 00:02:25.990
Well it's got a few defaults.

40
00:02:25.990 --> 00:02:28.650
It's gonna run the defaults type of scan,

41
00:02:28.650 --> 00:02:32.370
we'll get to that in just a little while
and I bet probably in the next episode.

42
00:02:32.370 --> 00:02:36.160
And it also it start
scanning the machines ports.

43
00:02:36.160 --> 00:02:39.070
And this is where something as just wanted
to make sure that you're aware of that you

44
00:02:39.070 --> 00:02:40.470
have this knowledge.

45
00:02:40.470 --> 00:02:44.730
Because you may want to make it act
differently, and that's fine, but

46
00:02:44.730 --> 00:02:49.010
you gotta know how it acts by default if
you're going to know how to work with it

47
00:02:50.520 --> 00:02:52.010
outside of those defaults.

48
00:02:52.010 --> 00:02:57.400
So the default way an nmap is gonna work,
it's gonna run a SYN scan, and

49
00:02:57.400 --> 00:03:01.970
it's gonna run that against the first
1,000 ports on your target computer.

50
00:03:01.970 --> 00:03:03.120
And you're thinking, cool!

51
00:03:03.120 --> 00:03:04.515
That's nice.

52
00:03:04.515 --> 00:03:06.510
1,000, that's a nice round number.

53
00:03:06.510 --> 00:03:10.720
And it is, and there's a good reason
it runs against the first 1,000 ports.

54
00:03:10.720 --> 00:03:14.885
That's because those are known as
the well-known ports are very common ports

55
00:03:14.885 --> 00:03:17.405
in which network services are running on.

56
00:03:17.405 --> 00:03:21.415
So, if you scan a machine, and
you do it against those first 1,000 ports,

57
00:03:21.415 --> 00:03:24.155
as nmap does, the good thing is is,

58
00:03:24.155 --> 00:03:29.035
if there is something running, it's
probably going to be in those 1,000 ports.

59
00:03:29.035 --> 00:03:30.465
Not necessarily, but

60
00:03:30.465 --> 00:03:35.970
it's a very good chance if that computer
is running some type of service.

61
00:03:35.970 --> 00:03:39.900
In those first 1,000 which are most
likely going to show that surface.

62
00:03:39.900 --> 00:03:41.340
>> Now Dan, I do have a question.

63
00:03:41.340 --> 00:03:45.320
When you mention those first 1,000 ports,
I know there's a lot, right?

64
00:03:45.320 --> 00:03:46.076
You mentioned it in earlier episode.

65
00:03:46.076 --> 00:03:46.622
>> 1,000 of them.
[LAUGH]

66
00:03:46.622 --> 00:03:50.120
>> There's 65,535 ports,

67
00:03:50.120 --> 00:03:52.423
that's a lot of ports to do some scanning.

68
00:03:52.423 --> 00:03:56.030
So, when you say well-known ports, ome of
the things that come to mid are things

69
00:03:56.030 --> 00:03:58.520
like your Email ports right,
things like Telnet,

70
00:03:58.520 --> 00:04:03.370
things like SSH, things like SMB traffic
if you're in a Windows network and

71
00:04:03.370 --> 00:04:05.020
these are some of the ports
that you are talking about?

72
00:04:05.020 --> 00:04:06.385
>> That is exactly right.

73
00:04:06.385 --> 00:04:08.660
Wes is been around the block a few times.

74
00:04:08.660 --> 00:04:11.430
He's work with ports himself
I'm sure you guys have as well.

75
00:04:11.430 --> 00:04:14.840
So this shouldn't be anything
too insanely new to you,

76
00:04:14.840 --> 00:04:18.350
you should be like okay all that makes
sense now that I know what nmap is doing I

77
00:04:18.350 --> 00:04:24.060
get that it should be looking for
things like Telnet and FTP and DNS and

78
00:04:24.060 --> 00:04:29.150
any other service SMTP or POP3 something

79
00:04:29.150 --> 00:04:34.470
of that nature those are gonna be found
usually within that first 1,000 ports.

80
00:04:34.470 --> 00:04:36.850
And that's the money, right.

81
00:04:36.850 --> 00:04:38.120
That's the good stuff.

82
00:04:38.120 --> 00:04:40.660
Now, it will also look for
other things as well but

83
00:04:40.660 --> 00:04:45.550
basically it might not necessarily be
looking for ports one through 1,000.

84
00:04:45.550 --> 00:04:48.120
Let me do make that distinction.

85
00:04:48.120 --> 00:04:52.160
It's looking for the most common ports
within the first common port range.

86
00:04:52.160 --> 00:04:56.560
As well as a few other ports that
are above that, that are also common,

87
00:04:56.560 --> 00:05:00.460
just they're outside of
the well-known port range, per se.

88
00:05:00.460 --> 00:05:02.320
All right, so let's keep that in mind.

89
00:05:02.320 --> 00:05:05.400
And that way if you say hey,
you've got port 8,000 something there.

90
00:05:05.400 --> 00:05:08.200
I go yes, I know, and
I know I told you it was the 1,000 ports.

91
00:05:08.200 --> 00:05:11.840
It's not specifically
the first 1,000 ports.

92
00:05:11.840 --> 00:05:16.720
It is a 1,000 ports, most of them in
the common or well-known port range.

93
00:05:16.720 --> 00:05:17.640
There we go.

94
00:05:17.640 --> 00:05:18.630
Disclaimer says so

95
00:05:18.630 --> 00:05:21.805
that way if I mess up horribly,
you guys can't hammer me too badly.

96
00:05:21.805 --> 00:05:25.830
[LAUGH] [INAUDIBLE] You guys
would never do that to me.

97
00:05:25.830 --> 00:05:26.870
>> That's a great point Dan.

98
00:05:26.870 --> 00:05:27.850
I thought about that.

99
00:05:27.850 --> 00:05:30.430
Until you mentioned it I would
have probably thought hey,

100
00:05:30.430 --> 00:05:33.390
you meant from zero to 1,000
in that well-known port range.

101
00:05:33.390 --> 00:05:34.160
But wait a second.

102
00:05:34.160 --> 00:05:36.990
Now I'm thinking well, there's a common
port out there that sits in the middle of

103
00:05:36.990 --> 00:05:38.640
those registered port ranges.

104
00:05:38.640 --> 00:05:40.120
And it's common to every Windows machine,
right?

105
00:05:40.120 --> 00:05:42.010
Now many of you out there are running RDP?

106
00:05:42.010 --> 00:05:45.480
Well RDP is port 3389 and that's
definitely not in the first 1,000 ports.

107
00:05:45.480 --> 00:05:47.120
So something like this,
is this what you mean?

108
00:05:47.120 --> 00:05:48.150
>> That's exactly right.

109
00:05:48.150 --> 00:05:49.910
And I'd almost guarantee.

110
00:05:49.910 --> 00:05:55.420
I need to find a list of exactly what
those 1,000 ports are that it scans.

111
00:05:55.420 --> 00:06:00.210
I just know that the vast majority
of them lie in, actually it's

112
00:06:00.210 --> 00:06:05.485
the first 1,048 or
28 ports if I'm not mistaken.

113
00:06:05.485 --> 00:06:08.560
1,024 ports is the well-known port range,
per se.

114
00:06:08.560 --> 00:06:13.200
But we do have a couple of those
very well-known ports like 3389 that

115
00:06:13.200 --> 00:06:17.030
sit obviously outside of 1,024.

116
00:06:17.030 --> 00:06:18.770
So that being said there we go.

117
00:06:18.770 --> 00:06:22.980
Hopefully that dispels any kind of,
well why am I getting this and

118
00:06:22.980 --> 00:06:24.320
those types of questions.

119
00:06:24.320 --> 00:06:28.870
Why am I seeing port 3389 when
I'm scanning a 1,000 ports?

120
00:06:28.870 --> 00:06:33.020
It just doesn't mean that it's one
through 1,000 like Wes had mentioned.

121
00:06:33.020 --> 00:06:36.010
All right,
now let's talk about port states.

122
00:06:36.010 --> 00:06:39.650
This is definitely the bread and
butter of this here episode.

123
00:06:39.650 --> 00:06:43.540
The thing about the 1,000 ports
is just informational for you, so

124
00:06:43.540 --> 00:06:44.550
that you would know that.

125
00:06:44.550 --> 00:06:47.319
But these port states are very,
very interesting information.

126
00:06:48.620 --> 00:06:50.010
So what do I mean by port states?

127
00:06:50.010 --> 00:06:53.400
It means is the port open,
is the port closed?

128
00:06:53.400 --> 00:06:59.330
What are the different responses or
reports that I might get from nmap,

129
00:06:59.330 --> 00:07:04.770
these labels for the ports that it has
found from the different scans, we'll

130
00:07:04.770 --> 00:07:09.930
get a multitude, actually, there are six
specific states that you might encounter

131
00:07:09.930 --> 00:07:13.460
with any nmap scan that you run, and
I'll just run through them really quickly.

132
00:07:13.460 --> 00:07:15.930
It's going to be open, closed.

133
00:07:15.930 --> 00:07:16.870
What else is it?

134
00:07:16.870 --> 00:07:19.090
Filtered, unfiltered.

135
00:07:19.090 --> 00:07:23.180
That it's open filtered and
closed filtered.

136
00:07:23.180 --> 00:07:27.410
Okay?
So, okay, kind of you had me for

137
00:07:27.410 --> 00:07:29.990
a little while, and
then now it's starting to get a little

138
00:07:29.990 --> 00:07:34.290
vague okay let's we'll get to that and
probably remove the veil.

139
00:07:34.290 --> 00:07:35.950
Hopefully we'll remove the veil for you so

140
00:07:35.950 --> 00:07:38.220
that makes a little more
sense as we get to it.

141
00:07:38.220 --> 00:07:39.330
Let's just start at the beginning, right.

142
00:07:39.330 --> 00:07:44.510
Open ports, what does that mean when
m maps says this port is open right.

143
00:07:44.510 --> 00:07:46.920
What it means is that there is a service,

144
00:07:46.920 --> 00:07:50.420
that is running on that port,
it is waiting and accepting connections.

145
00:07:50.420 --> 00:07:55.375
Right, so it's waiting for an accepting
connections, that come inbound to it.

146
00:07:55.375 --> 00:07:57.529
Right?
This is, SSH, it's a great one,

147
00:07:57.529 --> 00:08:02.938
it's sitting there, going, it's twiddling
it's thumbs and doing sitting around.

148
00:08:02.938 --> 00:08:07.894
And then when someone says at
a terminal or through a utility,

149
00:08:07.894 --> 00:08:13.134
SSH to this computer on this port,
and they hit the Enter button,

150
00:08:13.134 --> 00:08:17.270
they hit go, they hit do it,
hit execute, right?

151
00:08:17.270 --> 00:08:22.910
That computer sees the request come in on
that port and says that's SSH, that's me.

152
00:08:22.910 --> 00:08:24.200
I'm good to go.

We appreciate you,
the viewers out here, but

608
00:33:16.700 --> 00:33:18.740
we're gonna take the time to sign out for
ITProTV.

609
00:33:18.740 --> 00:33:20.270
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

610
00:33:20.270 --> 00:33:21.340
>> I'm Daniel Lowrie.

611
00:33:21.340 --> 00:33:23.885
>> And we'll see you next time.

612
00:33:23.885 --> 00:33:26.646
[MUSIC]

613
00:33:26.646 --> 00:33:31.380
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Dan explore port scans and their application inside of your network. They discuss the difference between privileged and non-privileged scans. They explain performing TCP versus UDP scans.
episodes.title: Port Scanning
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.160 --> 00:00:10.160
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.019 --> 00:00:16.600
Welcome back to another exciting episode
here in ITProTV, I'm you host Wes Bryan.

3
00:00:16.600 --> 00:00:21.330
And in today's episode we are continuing
along the series that is known as nmap.

4
00:00:21.330 --> 00:00:24.310
And joining me in the studios today
is none other than Mr. Dan Lowrie.

5
00:00:24.310 --> 00:00:25.340
Dan, how are you doing today sir?

6
00:00:25.340 --> 00:00:27.610
>> Man, I couldn't be happier
to be back in the studio today,

7
00:00:27.610 --> 00:00:29.720
because we've arrived.

8
00:00:29.720 --> 00:00:31.948
We're here.
We're actually gonna do some scanning,

9
00:00:31.948 --> 00:00:35.738
we're gonna scan machines, actually we
have scanned machines to be honest with

10
00:00:35.738 --> 00:00:38.096
you [LAUGH] have you been
watching up to this point?

11
00:00:38.096 --> 00:00:42.716
I've slipped in a scan here and there so
that we can look at the output but

12
00:00:42.716 --> 00:00:45.950
today is all about the scan
process itself right.

13
00:00:45.950 --> 00:00:51.030
What kind of scans are available, and
I'm just gonna go ahead and warn you

14
00:00:51.030 --> 00:00:56.380
there I think about a dozen different
types of port scans, specifically,

15
00:00:56.380 --> 00:01:00.350
that nmap does, so we are not going
to make it through all of them today.

16
00:01:00.350 --> 00:01:04.410
We're going to get through some of
them today and this will definitely

17
00:01:04.410 --> 00:01:08.690
be a multi-parter, so just keep that in
mind that there is no way [LAUGH] I'm

18
00:01:08.690 --> 00:01:12.920
getting through all 12, it's just way
too much information about each one for

19
00:01:12.920 --> 00:01:15.270
us to be able to hit all of
them at one point in time.

20
00:01:15.270 --> 00:01:20.040
So let's talk about the ones that we
are going to talk about today, in fact.

21
00:01:20.040 --> 00:01:22.630
And let's talk about
port scanning in general.

22
00:01:23.990 --> 00:01:27.850
First thing I want you guys to
understand about port scanning is well,

23
00:01:27.850 --> 00:01:29.070
what's happening, right.

24
00:01:29.070 --> 00:01:35.080
What I'm doing, is I'm telling nmap to
send packets, toward a target machine,

25
00:01:35.080 --> 00:01:39.150
to again, as we said over and over again,
to elicit some sort of response.

26
00:01:39.150 --> 00:01:42.810
And the response that I want to know is,
is there a port that is open?

27
00:01:42.810 --> 00:01:43.740
Is it closed?

28
00:01:43.740 --> 00:01:44.390
Is it filtered?

29
00:01:44.390 --> 00:01:48.940
I wanna know everything I
can know about my target for

30
00:01:48.940 --> 00:01:53.270
the purposes of,
if I'm black hat, exploitation.

31
00:01:53.270 --> 00:01:58.270
If I'm a white hat, I'm a security
specialist, a network admin,

32
00:01:58.270 --> 00:02:02.630
of some sort, for the purposes of,
closing vulnerability.

33
00:02:02.630 --> 00:02:05.350
So one's looking for open vulnerabilities,
one's looking for them so

34
00:02:05.350 --> 00:02:08.990
that they can close them, or at least
mitigate them as a problem, right.

35
00:02:08.990 --> 00:02:11.300
So that's why we're doing port scanning.

36
00:02:11.300 --> 00:02:17.940
And of course, nmap by default, scans the
thousand common most used ports, right.

37
00:02:17.940 --> 00:02:20.649
Again, not 1 through 1,000 but

38
00:02:20.649 --> 00:02:26.080
even though I'm sure the vast majority
of them lie within that range.

39
00:02:26.080 --> 00:02:30.200
It is the most commonly used ports and
there are typically a thousand of them.

40
00:02:30.200 --> 00:02:31.220
>> All right.
>> Not typically,

41
00:02:31.220 --> 00:02:32.340
there are a thousand of them.

42
00:02:32.340 --> 00:02:34.640
I wanna be very,
very solid in my speech there.

43
00:02:36.000 --> 00:02:40.050
I do wanna talk about, and
again kinda going back to some reminders,

44
00:02:40.050 --> 00:02:45.980
some things to help us keep going is
privileged versus nonprivileged use, okay?

45
00:02:45.980 --> 00:02:50.780
If you run a port scan,
if you run a host discovery,

46
00:02:50.780 --> 00:02:54.920
running it as a route, or
power user, an administrator,

47
00:02:54.920 --> 00:02:58.890
is going to work differently than if
you were running it as a standard user.

48
00:02:58.890 --> 00:03:01.380
Someone without privileged
rights to the machine.

49
00:03:01.380 --> 00:03:04.380
And this is important for us to know,
we gotta figure this out,

50
00:03:04.380 --> 00:03:08.500
we gotta understand what's happening
if I'm not a privileged user.

51
00:03:08.500 --> 00:03:11.980
Now the cool thing about nmap
it knows when you're okay.

52
00:03:11.980 --> 00:03:15.665
You might not be the king of this castle,
and because of that, you gotta remember,

53
00:03:15.665 --> 00:03:21.380
nmap was, I think it was 1997 when
it came out, somewhere around there.

54
00:03:21.380 --> 00:03:25.600
And back then computers
were relatively expensive,

55
00:03:25.600 --> 00:03:27.390
at least more expensive than they are now.

56
00:03:27.390 --> 00:03:29.350
Much cheaper nowadays to grab a laptop.

57
00:03:29.350 --> 00:03:33.030
I think you can go to Best Buy or
something and pick up a laptop for

58
00:03:33.030 --> 00:03:34.550
300 bucks or even cheaper.

59
00:03:34.550 --> 00:03:36.800
It's super cheap, right?

60
00:03:36.800 --> 00:03:38.790
Most people,
if they're in a Unix environment,

61
00:03:38.790 --> 00:03:42.730
probably have some sort of shared
shell that they logged into.

62
00:03:42.730 --> 00:03:46.750
And they didn't have full privileges to
that environment, wasn't there machine,

63
00:03:46.750 --> 00:03:48.260
they just had rights to login.

64
00:03:48.260 --> 00:03:52.780
Maybe you were at a university of some
sort and they gave you shell access.

65
00:03:52.780 --> 00:03:56.040
If you're a computer science major,
something like that, they gave you that.

66
00:03:56.040 --> 00:03:58.520
So it wasn't your system.

67
00:03:58.520 --> 00:03:59.970
We don't live in those days any more so

68
00:03:59.970 --> 00:04:03.980
this isn't as much of a problem
as it used to be, all right?

69
00:04:03.980 --> 00:04:08.440
Before so the developers of nmap said,

70
00:04:08.440 --> 00:04:12.360
well since you don't have the ability
we're gonna try to do some finagling,

71
00:04:12.360 --> 00:04:15.980
we're gonna do what we can to get you
as much information as possible, and

72
00:04:15.980 --> 00:04:18.860
we're gonna talk about that in more
detail here in just a few minutes.

73
00:04:18.860 --> 00:04:22.900
But just remember root users,
definitely the way to go.

74
00:04:22.900 --> 00:04:27.520
You have more control because you
have the ability to do things like

75
00:04:27.520 --> 00:04:30.900
control the raw data, and
that's really what it boils down to.

76
00:04:30.900 --> 00:04:35.250
That's the brass tacks difference between
privilege to none-privilege users.

77
00:04:35.250 --> 00:04:40.460
We have to find other means of
elicitation from our target computer

78
00:04:40.460 --> 00:04:43.290
through a different means of using nmap
when we don't have that privilege.

79
00:04:43.290 --> 00:04:47.280
So keep that mind, that is something
that you want to be aware of.

80
00:04:47.280 --> 00:04:49.380
If you throw an Nmap scan at something,

81
00:04:49.380 --> 00:04:53.220
it doesn't quite reply the way
in which you think it should.

82
00:04:53.220 --> 00:04:55.970
Maybe it's because I forgot to that,
all right.

83
00:04:55.970 --> 00:05:00.160
Cuz obviously it's a very bad practice
to logged in as root all the time.

84
00:05:00.160 --> 00:05:03.827
So you'll see me throw at
this thing all the time.

85
00:05:03.827 --> 00:05:06.609
And that's because I want
that elevated privilege.

86
00:05:06.609 --> 00:05:11.800
All right, so also,
we did talk about this in Host Discovery,

87
00:05:11.800 --> 00:05:16.320
if I do an unprivileged scan,
it has a specific language it does that.

88
00:05:16.320 --> 00:05:20.530
It does what's called a TCP connect scan,
okay.

89
00:05:20.530 --> 00:05:24.590
It basically simulates a SYN scan.

90
00:05:24.590 --> 00:05:29.590
Don't worry if you're going SYN scan, TCP
scan, I don't know what's going on here.

91
00:05:29.590 --> 00:05:31.930
Don't worry we're going to get
here in just a few minutes,

92
00:05:31.930 --> 00:05:33.770
into those scans specifically.

93
00:05:33.770 --> 00:05:35.660
But if that's its way of
working it around, so

94
00:05:35.660 --> 00:05:39.660
it's basically if you do m map target and

95
00:05:39.660 --> 00:05:44.720
you're unprivileged user it's basically
doing a dash st which is a TCP scan.

96
00:05:44.720 --> 00:05:46.220
And like I said,
in just a few minutes here,

97
00:05:46.220 --> 00:05:49.040
we'll we'll describe
exactly what that means.

98
00:05:49.040 --> 00:05:53.934
So now that you know that, we can move
ahead and start really unraveling

99
00:05:53.934 --> 00:05:59.095
this onion, or to peeling away the layers
of the onion that is nmap port scanning.

100
00:05:59.095 --> 00:06:02.785
So the first one we're gonna
start with is the default scan,

101
00:06:02.785 --> 00:06:06.535
which is the SYN scan, the -ss.

102
00:06:06.535 --> 00:06:12.355
Now if I type in nmap target machine,
or sudo nmap target machine if I'm

103
00:06:12.355 --> 00:06:16.330
not a privileged user, sudo nmap target
machine that's what it runs by default.

104
00:06:16.330 --> 00:06:21.190
I don't have to throw the dash
ss at it to make it do this.

105
00:06:21.190 --> 00:06:22.730
This is just what it does by default.

106
00:06:22.730 --> 00:06:26.560
So it's funny that those
flags are still around from

107
00:06:26.560 --> 00:06:30.959
harkening back from old from
ye old days of nmaps yor.

108
00:06:30.959 --> 00:06:33.220
It's still there.

109
00:06:33.220 --> 00:06:37.600
And it's helpful to know
what they are in your head.

110
00:06:37.600 --> 00:06:40.200
So I know I'm running that SYN scan,
that dash SS.

111
00:06:40.200 --> 00:06:44.160
That's also known as a stealth scan and
there's good reason for that.

112
00:06:44.160 --> 00:06:45.830
And I'm glad you asked why, right?

113
00:06:45.830 --> 00:06:48.420
Why is that a good reason,
what is that good reason?

114
00:06:48.420 --> 00:06:50.700
The good reason is that it's quick.

115
00:06:50.700 --> 00:06:53.350
Superfast and it's stealthy.

116
00:06:53.350 --> 00:06:56.090
You say, how's it, what does that mean?

117
00:06:56.090 --> 00:06:57.520
What does it mean that it's quick?

118
00:06:57.520 --> 00:06:59.290
And what does it mean that it's stealthy?

119
00:06:59.290 --> 00:07:02.090
Well, it's fast and
people can't detect it, right.

120
00:07:02.090 --> 00:07:06.620
I know, right, that's the facetious
answer, the quick and dirty answer.

121
00:07:06.620 --> 00:07:08.760
Let's dive into that a little bit more.

122
00:07:08.760 --> 00:07:13.901
When we say that it's quick,
it means that because of how it works is

123
00:07:13.901 --> 00:07:19.149
why it's fast okay and that's what
important for us to understand.

124
00:07:19.149 --> 00:07:24.689
Is I'm creating a connection
I'm sending right we talking

125
00:07:24.689 --> 00:07:30.689
about this I'm sending a scene
flagged tcp packet to a machine.

126
00:07:30.689 --> 00:07:35.970
And it's either going to be in open
court and it will respond with a snap

127
00:07:35.970 --> 00:07:41.699
right in which case my in map machine will
move on with an rst because we really

128
00:07:41.699 --> 00:07:47.893
to create a full connection we don't want
to complete the three-way handshake.

129
00:07:47.893 --> 00:07:51.653
I don't need to,
I don't need to make that full connection.

130
00:07:51.653 --> 00:07:53.740
I just wanna know whether or
not the port's open.

131
00:07:53.740 --> 00:07:57.740
If I get that synac I know it's open,
you've responded.

132
00:07:57.740 --> 00:07:59.683
It's giving me information.

133
00:07:59.683 --> 00:08:01.890
Thank you very much I'm on my happy way.

134
00:08:01.890 --> 00:08:05.097
But that's the important,
that's the key of how why is this fast.

135
00:08:05.097 --> 00:08:07.416
I'm not creating full connections.

136
00:08:07.416 --> 00:08:09.247
I'm sending out there.

137
00:08:09.247 --> 00:08:10.900
If I get Synac boom, I'm done.

138
00:08:10.900 --> 00:08:13.930
There's my RST, I'm off to the next port.

139
00:08:13.930 --> 00:08:15.190
It's super quick.

140
00:08:15.190 --> 00:08:16.230
So it cuts the time down.

141
00:08:16.230 --> 00:08:18.290
If the port is closed, it's even faster.

142
00:08:18.290 --> 00:08:22.013
Cuz what's the first thing I'm
gonna get from a closed port?

143
00:08:22.013 --> 00:08:22.746
Anyone?
Bueller?

144
00:08:22.746 --> 00:08:24.950
Bueller?
It's going to be RST.

145
00:08:24.950 --> 00:08:25.920
I'm not an open port.

146
00:08:25.920 --> 00:08:27.940
I'm not supposed to be receiving.

147
00:08:27.940 --> 00:08:28.770
Network activity.

148
00:08:28.770 --> 00:08:30.040
Here's your RST.

149
00:08:30.040 --> 00:08:31.250
Please reset your connection.

150
00:08:31.250 --> 00:08:33.070
You've got the wrong guy.

151
00:08:33.070 --> 00:08:34.080
Thanks a lot.

152
00:08:34.080 --> 00:08:35.580
And for this very reason,

153
00:08:35.580 --> 00:08:39.940
they tend to call this a,
what's it called, a half open.

154
00:08:39.940 --> 00:08:41.760
They call it half open scan,

155
00:08:41.760 --> 00:08:46.940
because I'm not creating full TCP
connections, open connections, right?

156
00:08:46.940 --> 00:08:48.260
They're not fully connecting,

157
00:08:48.260 --> 00:08:52.130
they're only half opening, either by
getting that RST back from the target.

158
00:08:52.130 --> 00:08:55.480
Or getting the Synac because
the port is open and responding but

159
00:08:55.480 --> 00:08:59.940
either way we're killing it after we
know that the port is open or closed and

160
00:08:59.940 --> 00:09:01.160
it's stopping right then and there.

161
00:09:01.160 --> 00:09:03.930
So half open scan is something
that you might run into,

162
00:09:03.930 --> 00:09:08.020
just keep that in mind
it's the nomenclature or

163
00:09:08.020 --> 00:09:12.110
the the dialect of working with Nmap,
right.

164
00:09:12.110 --> 00:09:13.430
Some of the things you'll pick up.

165
00:09:13.430 --> 00:09:16.080
It's like being in the military,
you get your own type of language and

166
00:09:16.080 --> 00:09:16.640
it's a lot of fun.

167
00:09:17.950 --> 00:09:21.742
All right, let's see, what else do
we need to know about the sendscan?

168
00:09:21.742 --> 00:09:25.870
All right, so we do know it sends
a tcp packet with the send flag and

169
00:09:25.870 --> 00:09:28.500
then it responds with either the Synac or
the rst.

170
00:09:29.670 --> 00:09:32.370
Also, what happens if I
don't receive a response?

171
00:09:32.370 --> 00:09:34.070
What happens there, right?

172
00:09:34.070 --> 00:09:38.260
Probably gonna get that filtered,
right, because open and

173
00:09:38.260 --> 00:09:43.550
closed ports should be sending
some sort of response back to my

174
00:09:43.550 --> 00:09:46.380
attacking computer,
my end map machine, right?

175
00:09:46.380 --> 00:09:48.220
It should be giving me something?

176
00:09:48.220 --> 00:09:52.900
Should have either given me that RST going
I'm closed or Synac going hey I'm open,

177
00:09:52.900 --> 00:09:55.080
do you want to get some talking going,

178
00:09:55.080 --> 00:09:57.720
want to build a relationship,
want to get a connection, right?

179
00:09:57.720 --> 00:09:59.600
That's what should be happening,

180
00:09:59.600 --> 00:10:04.430
if nothing comes back well then
Nmap is going to conclude that

181
00:10:04.430 --> 00:10:08.650
this is probably a filtered port because
I should be receiving something.

182
00:10:08.650 --> 00:10:12.240
Now there are other reasons in
which it might not be responding,

183
00:10:12.240 --> 00:10:13.870
network congestion, things of that nature.

184
00:10:13.870 --> 00:10:19.800
And again we talk about how because
Nmap is very thorough it tries

185
00:10:19.800 --> 00:10:23.540
to retry over and over and over again just
to make sure it wasn't network congestion.

186
00:10:23.540 --> 00:10:27.130
If it sees that consistent no response

187
00:10:27.130 --> 00:10:31.020
again it still could
be network congestion.

188
00:10:31.020 --> 00:10:34.690
But, at this point, it's gonna go ahead,
and guess that it is a filtered state.

189
00:10:36.290 --> 00:10:41.810
And, I did wanna take a random aside,
to just talk about that, because, Wes,

190
00:10:41.810 --> 00:10:46.940
what do you think that the answer,
if I'm an N Map scanner, I'm the bad guy.

191
00:10:46.940 --> 00:10:48.360
And you're the good guy.

192
00:10:48.360 --> 00:10:51.980
You've got a machine, you've got a server
of some sort, and I start scanning your

193
00:10:51.980 --> 00:10:56.520
machine and I wanna get telnet,
or I wanna get SSH let's say SSH.

194
00:10:56.520 --> 00:10:58.160
SSH is my thing.

195
00:10:58.160 --> 00:10:58.750
I'd go for that.

196
00:10:59.760 --> 00:11:02.690
What are you going to do as an admin
to stop me from doing that?

197
00:11:02.690 --> 00:11:05.830
>> Well, the first thing I would do is
just take the service itself that uses

198
00:11:05.830 --> 00:11:07.070
that port and close it down.

199
00:11:07.070 --> 00:11:10.790
And, well, we should have a closed
port and hopefully we would be secure.

200
00:11:10.790 --> 00:11:14.630
>> That's a great answer,
what if you need SSH?

201
00:11:14.630 --> 00:11:16.170
>> Well then we're going to
have to leave the port open and

202
00:11:16.170 --> 00:11:17.180
we're going to be unsecure.

203
00:11:17.180 --> 00:11:18.660
>> Right, so what do we do, right?

204
00:11:18.660 --> 00:11:24.330
I either have to leave it open and allow
the attacker to know this port is open.

205
00:11:24.330 --> 00:11:30.210
But typically a security avenue to get
around that is what people do, right?

206
00:11:30.210 --> 00:11:34.528
And what they do is they
filter the port from everyone

207
00:11:34.528 --> 00:11:38.410
except certain people right,
certain machines.

208
00:11:38.410 --> 00:11:39.750
So that's the way you can get around this.

209
00:11:39.750 --> 00:11:44.280
I can at least filter the port, you might
even still understand that it's open but

210
00:11:44.280 --> 00:11:48.230
I wanted to show you this, right, just to
give you an idea of how these give and

211
00:11:48.230 --> 00:11:48.740
takes works.

212
00:11:48.740 --> 00:11:51.540
So let's look at my
machine really quickly.

213
00:11:51.540 --> 00:11:55.910
And what I'm gonna do is, we'll just
do a quick Nmap scan, sudu Nmap.

214
00:11:55.910 --> 00:11:57.570
And remember I don't need any flags or

215
00:11:57.570 --> 00:12:00.840
arguments at this point cuz I'm
doing the standard SYN scan.

216
00:12:00.840 --> 00:12:04.955
Against my metasploitable.

217
00:12:04.955 --> 00:12:05.868
Metasploitable.

218
00:12:05.868 --> 00:12:06.598
