00:24:50.350 --> 00:24:52.740
Maybe that UDP port is being used.

449
00:24:52.740 --> 00:24:53.460
Who knows?

450
00:24:53.460 --> 00:24:55.820
This is does DACP,
very common, very common.

451
00:24:57.290 --> 00:25:00.710
NetBIOS going on here, NFS, right?

452
00:25:00.710 --> 00:25:02.130
This is a great system.

453
00:25:02.130 --> 00:25:04.140
So, don't forget to run your UDP.

454
00:25:04.140 --> 00:25:07.180
Let's see,
what else do we want to know about this?

455
00:25:07.180 --> 00:25:12.260
It can be run simultaneously
with the Stealth scan, right?

456
00:25:12.260 --> 00:25:15.820
So, I can do SU-SS, right, do both.

457
00:25:15.820 --> 00:25:16.520
Run them at the same time.

458
00:25:16.520 --> 00:25:20.280
Now it'll still take a long time because
both scans have to finish before it gives

459
00:25:20.280 --> 00:25:21.420
me my results.

460
00:25:21.420 --> 00:25:24.750
But, I'm making it really run faster

461
00:25:24.750 --> 00:25:27.690
in the long run because I'm not running
one scan and then running another.

462
00:25:27.690 --> 00:25:29.190
I'm combining them together.

463
00:25:29.190 --> 00:25:30.890
That's the nice thing.

464
00:25:32.250 --> 00:25:35.880
Open and filtered ports usually
do not respond to Nmap.

465
00:25:35.880 --> 00:25:43.020
So, it will retry, to make a connections
snd this slows things down, right.

466
00:25:43.020 --> 00:25:46.836
So, because of the nature of UDP
not responding, what does it think?

467
00:25:46.836 --> 00:25:49.376
Well maybe there's network congestion,
maybe something happened and

468
00:25:49.376 --> 00:25:50.540
the packet got dropped.

469
00:25:50.540 --> 00:25:52.930
Let me try again, let me try again.

470
00:25:52.930 --> 00:25:55.560
Slowing things down,
this is why it takes so long.

471
00:25:55.560 --> 00:25:57.730
Plus, some hosts can do rate limiting.

472
00:25:57.730 --> 00:26:01.810
Linux and Solaris,
they're notorious for this.

473
00:26:01.810 --> 00:26:04.190
They start receiving a ton of traffic,
and they say,

474
00:26:04.190 --> 00:26:07.100
whoa buddy, we need to slow our roll.

475
00:26:07.100 --> 00:26:08.618
And let's do, how about,

476
00:26:08.618 --> 00:26:12.540
I think the default on Linux
is one message per second.

477
00:26:12.540 --> 00:26:15.850
Now the cool thing is that Nmap says,
I'm in a rate limited environment,

478
00:26:15.850 --> 00:26:18.650
I need to calm myself down.

479
00:26:18.650 --> 00:26:19.620
But, what does that mean?

480
00:26:19.620 --> 00:26:20.420
It slows down.

481
00:26:20.420 --> 00:26:28.590
So it's all these things that work against
UDP's speed as a scan that it's doing.

482
00:26:28.590 --> 00:26:32.320
So this rate limiting can
cause big slow downs,

483
00:26:32.320 --> 00:26:36.260
the one message per second coming from
a Linux box can cause slow downs and

484
00:26:36.260 --> 00:26:40.070
Nmap itself is slowing it down
to hit that rate limiting thing.

485
00:26:40.070 --> 00:26:44.170
Couple of things we can do to speed things
up, scan multiple hosts simultaneously.

486
00:26:44.170 --> 00:26:49.270
Get five, ten machines and get some
really juicy stuff that you wanna scan.

487
00:26:49.270 --> 00:26:51.480
Run it all at one time
against all those targets.

488
00:26:51.480 --> 00:26:52.210
One spot, right?

489
00:26:53.450 --> 00:26:57.480
Another thing we can do is
skip slow hosts, right?

490
00:26:57.480 --> 00:27:03.610
If Nmap detects and you add a flag,
it's the --host timeout.

491
00:27:03.610 --> 00:27:08.150
So if I ran, let's take a look just so
you can see it in practicum.

492
00:27:08.150 --> 00:27:14.210
So if I was running this scan and
I did --host-timeout like that,

493
00:27:14.210 --> 00:27:20.050
then if a host took longer than a certain
amount of time to reply, it just skips it.

494
00:27:20.050 --> 00:27:23.490
It just says, you're taking too
long I'm trying to be fast here.

495
00:27:23.490 --> 00:27:28.180
To speed things up, I'm gonna just jump
by you, and go on to the next thing.

496
00:27:28.180 --> 00:27:31.440
So that can help speed things up as well.

497
00:27:31.440 --> 00:27:36.842
Interesting thing about UDP is for
common UDP services,

498
00:27:36.842 --> 00:27:42.131
common user ports, it will,
typically when Nmap sends

499
00:27:42.131 --> 00:27:47.442
a scan it is an empty packet
with just a flag set, right?

500
00:27:47.442 --> 00:27:52.120
Just empty with all the necessary things
needed to go across a network connection.

501
00:27:52.120 --> 00:27:54.730
And make a connection, right?

502
00:27:54.730 --> 00:27:55.410
Just no data in it.

503
00:27:56.410 --> 00:28:01.970
But with a UDP scan for the common ports,
it will actually put in a specific

504
00:28:01.970 --> 00:28:07.040
payload for those common types
of services, like in DNS, right?

505
00:28:07.040 --> 00:28:08.560
That's a great example.

506
00:28:08.560 --> 00:28:13.270
It'll put a payload in it,
will help illicit a response more often.

507
00:28:13.270 --> 00:28:15.440
Right?
So if some sort of filtering is happening,

508
00:28:15.440 --> 00:28:17.520
or empty packets.

509
00:28:17.520 --> 00:28:20.370
Don't accept empty packets
with just a send flag set.

510
00:28:20.370 --> 00:28:23.480
And it's dropping that, well,
now I'm adding a payload to it, so

511
00:28:23.480 --> 00:28:25.090
now it accepts those packets.

512
00:28:25.090 --> 00:28:26.620
So a very good thing to know.

513
00:28:26.620 --> 00:28:29.230
>> So it might be doing something,
and I'm just taking a guess here, and

514
00:28:29.230 --> 00:28:31.000
we might not have any answer on this one.

515
00:28:31.000 --> 00:28:34.060
But if it is something like DNS,
rather than like you said,

516
00:28:34.060 --> 00:28:37.140
just an empty shell of a packet
going across the wire,

517
00:28:37.140 --> 00:28:39.840
in this case virtualized network, [LAUGH]
we're really not leaving the computer,

518
00:28:39.840 --> 00:28:44.090
but Going across the wire, we might
put maybe a resolver query in that.

519
00:28:44.090 --> 00:28:49.070
It could be arbitrary data, but it could
be something specific that when you send

520
00:28:49.070 --> 00:28:52.810
it to the endpoint, would be something
that the DNS server goes, I realize this.

521
00:28:52.810 --> 00:28:54.820
This is my whole purpose of existence.

522
00:28:54.820 --> 00:28:57.150
Help me send that back,
fire it back to your Nmap scanner.

523
00:28:57.150 --> 00:28:58.870
>> Yeah,
that's definitely part of the equation,

524
00:28:58.870 --> 00:29:02.890
is that DNS system says,
this is definitely for me.

525
00:29:02.890 --> 00:29:04.110
Let me respond to that.

526
00:29:04.110 --> 00:29:07.300
But it's also, the other half of
that is to get around the firewall.

527
00:29:07.300 --> 00:29:07.830
Right?

528
00:29:07.830 --> 00:29:09.510
So two things in conjunction.

529
00:29:09.510 --> 00:29:13.750
And that does that for
common services by default, right?

530
00:29:13.750 --> 00:29:17.500
If you want to add data to
empty packets that are for

531
00:29:17.500 --> 00:29:20.850
other ports, you can do that as well.

532
00:29:20.850 --> 00:29:24.830
You can add the Dash,
dash, data arguments.

533
00:29:24.830 --> 00:29:31.480
Which basically says, I think it works
in hexidecimal, you put hexidecimal

534
00:29:31.480 --> 00:29:36.420
values in there, and it just pads
the packet itself, gives it some data.

535
00:29:36.420 --> 00:29:40.790
You can do dash dash data dash string,
Right?

536
00:29:40.790 --> 00:29:44.630
And this will actually allow you to
type something in, some actual content.

537
00:29:44.630 --> 00:29:49.550
You can put you were super hacked
by elite hacker group Elite, or

538
00:29:49.550 --> 00:29:50.570
whatever you wanna call yourself.

539
00:29:50.570 --> 00:29:52.720
I don't know, have a good time with it.

540
00:29:52.720 --> 00:29:54.520
The good thing is, again, most likely,

541
00:29:54.520 --> 00:29:57.830
someone's not paying attention to
what's inside of those data packets.

542
00:29:57.830 --> 00:30:00.350
Running WireShark, or
whatever at that point in time.

543
00:30:00.350 --> 00:30:01.990
So, have fun with it.

544
00:30:01.990 --> 00:30:03.700
Just, you're just giving it some data,

545
00:30:03.700 --> 00:30:06.900
so that it'll make it
through those types of scans.

546
00:30:06.900 --> 00:30:09.620
And then dash, dash, data dash, length.

547
00:30:09.620 --> 00:30:13.820
Which gives it random
data that Nmap produces,

548
00:30:13.820 --> 00:30:16.080
puts it in there again just
to give you some padding.

549
00:30:17.400 --> 00:30:19.500
Okay so last, but not least,

550
00:30:19.500 --> 00:30:25.240
we're talking about the results of
these scans, right, the states.

551
00:30:25.240 --> 00:30:26.300
Looking at my computer.

552
00:30:26.300 --> 00:30:29.080
You notice we've got some open.

553
00:30:29.080 --> 00:30:30.750
We've got open filter.

554
00:30:30.750 --> 00:30:35.110
I'm not seeing any closed, but
there's reasons why you might see open and

555
00:30:35.110 --> 00:30:36.700
there's reasons why you
might see open filter.

556
00:30:36.700 --> 00:30:41.340
There's another one that elicits the open
filtered response, very cool, right.

557
00:30:41.340 --> 00:30:42.830
So let's go do that.

558
00:30:42.830 --> 00:30:48.800
If it gives the target computer
replies with an ICMP unreachable

559
00:30:48.800 --> 00:30:53.190
Type Three code three I know
that's very specific, but

560
00:30:53.190 --> 00:30:56.610
if that's what it responds with then this
all comes from the firewall or whatever.

561
00:30:57.780 --> 00:31:03.190
Then it shows it as closed, that then the
UDP scan says well this is a closed port.

562
00:31:03.190 --> 00:31:06.360
All right, so just food for thought.

563
00:31:06.360 --> 00:31:10.850
You don't have to keep that and go, hey,
did you know it was a ICMP type three,

564
00:31:10.850 --> 00:31:11.868
code three.

565
00:31:11.868 --> 00:31:17.650
And then Nmap UDP scan will elicit
a closed state in the port response.

566
00:31:17.650 --> 00:31:22.373
So, yeah, that's basically what you
can do is talk cool at parties.

567
00:31:22.373 --> 00:31:25.460
[LAUGH] Going to other
ICMP unreachable replies.

568
00:31:25.460 --> 00:31:27.830
Things like, again,
it's in the type three.

569
00:31:29.070 --> 00:31:35.690
Code 0, 1, 2, 9, 10, and
13 will give you a filtered response.

570
00:31:35.690 --> 00:31:38.270
All right?
So if you get filtered back, that's why.

571
00:31:38.270 --> 00:31:41.470
And you can look these codes up on
why that's happening, but just so

572
00:31:41.470 --> 00:31:45.340
you know, when you pop the hood on Nmap,
what's happening?

573
00:31:45.340 --> 00:31:50.270
That's why you're getting filtered
back in the state column, okay.

574
00:31:50.270 --> 00:31:53.624
Nmap receives, if Nmap receives
the UDP packet back right,

575
00:31:53.624 --> 00:31:56.010
obviously that's gonna be open, right.

576
00:31:56.010 --> 00:32:00.560
The port is open,
it's responding and doing the thing,

577
00:32:00.560 --> 00:32:05.020
also if you receive closed
you might even get that.

578
00:32:05.020 --> 00:32:09.290
But not close, I'm sorry, if it responds
with an RC or doesn't respond at all,

579
00:32:09.290 --> 00:32:10.690
it might actually give you something.

580
00:32:10.690 --> 00:32:16.170
But if you do get that UDP packet back,
it will show it as being open, all right?

581
00:32:16.170 --> 00:32:19.540
And then, no response at all,
well, we see that right here.

582
00:32:19.540 --> 00:32:23.360
We're getting open, but
it's actually being filtered, right.

583
00:32:23.360 --> 00:32:24.640
Or it doesn't know.

584
00:32:24.640 --> 00:32:30.250
It thinks this could be open, it could be
filtered, I'm not receiving a response so

585
00:32:30.250 --> 00:32:32.930
I can't tell which one this is so
I'm gonna just kind of give you both.

586
00:32:32.930 --> 00:32:37.500
And you decide, or maybe run a different
type of scan to elicit whether or

587
00:32:37.500 --> 00:32:40.890
not it is open and
truly verify these things.

588
00:32:40.890 --> 00:32:45.380
That's basically the different types
of responses that you're gonna see, so

589
00:32:45.380 --> 00:32:47.100
I'm looking at our clock.

590
00:32:47.100 --> 00:32:51.220
I know Wes, he's giving me the evil eye
saying hey boy, that's enough of that.

591
00:32:51.220 --> 00:32:52.240
We've got more shows to do.

592
00:32:52.240 --> 00:32:55.030
So That's a a good stopping spot for us.

593
00:32:55.030 --> 00:32:56.500
>> That's great, it's kinda interesting.

594
00:32:56.500 --> 00:32:59.390
I was thinking Dan,
when you talked about what was that type,

595
00:32:59.390 --> 00:33:01.980
that was data string, right?

596
00:33:01.980 --> 00:33:05.690
Maybe you've got somebody on your
network who works for the company and

597
00:33:05.690 --> 00:33:06.880
is doing some kinda auditing.

598
00:33:06.880 --> 00:33:10.910
They've got Wireshark open, wouldn't that
be good to say in the data packet are you

599
00:33:10.910 --> 00:33:13.620
really paying attention and we'll see if
we're getting our money's worth or not.

600
00:33:13.620 --> 00:33:17.071
>> That would be boring
>> [LAUGH] Great information, Dan,

601
00:33:17.071 --> 00:33:18.218
thanks for that.

602
00:33:18.218 --> 00:33:21.483
Got any more information
before we part ways?

603
00:33:21.483 --> 00:33:26.420
>> No, just read over the man pages and
obviously insecure.org or nmap.org.

604
00:33:26.420 --> 00:33:30.250
It's a wealth of information that's gonna
help you remember these things if you've

605
00:33:30.250 --> 00:33:34.300
got Nmap installed, the man page is great,
and it's got tons of information.

606
00:33:34.300 --> 00:33:37.300
Basically, where I'm eliciting
just about all of this stuff.

607
00:33:37.300 --> 00:33:40.210
I mean, if you've worked with Nmap,
you're in that manual page, so

608
00:33:40.210 --> 00:33:41.640
definitely use that.

609
00:33:41.640 --> 00:33:45.185
We don't expect Don't expect you to
have this stuff memorized after one

610
00:33:45.185 --> 00:33:46.445
day of looking it over.

611
00:33:46.445 --> 00:33:50.795
So, go through it but
we do want you to be familiar with it and

612
00:33:50.795 --> 00:33:54.865
as you work with it more you will become
like, I know exactly what's happening when

613
00:33:54.865 --> 00:34:00.115
I do an SS scan and that's gonna hope
you be a better security specialist for

614
00:34:00.115 --> 00:34:03.410
both your own companies and if you're
doing like penetration testing, so.

615
00:34:03.410 --> 00:34:06.540
>> Dan, we appreciate all the information
you've given here and we appreciate you,

616
00:34:06.540 --> 00:34:07.490
the viewers out here.

617
00:34:07.490 --> 00:34:10.000
But we're gonna go ahead and
take this time to sign off for ITProTV.

618
00:34:10.000 --> 00:34:11.820
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

619
00:34:11.820 --> 00:34:12.540
>> I'm Daniel Lowrie.

620
00:34:12.540 --> 00:34:14.786
>> And we'll see you next time.

621
00:34:14.786 --> 00:34:20.709
[NOISE]

episodes.title: Port Scanning Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.677 --> 00:00:14.255
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.255 --> 00:00:15.619
I'm your host Wes Bryan,

4
00:00:15.619 --> 00:00:19.031
and in today's episode we're
coming back at you with more Nmap.

5
00:00:19.031 --> 00:00:22.490
That's right, more of that networking
software that you love and

6
00:00:22.490 --> 00:00:24.570
it's actually a part two in port scanning.

7
00:00:24.570 --> 00:00:27.130
Joining me back in the studios is
none other than Mr. Dan Lowrie.

8
00:00:27.130 --> 00:00:28.120
Dan, how you doing, sir?

9
00:00:28.120 --> 00:00:29.080
>> Man, I'm doing great.

10
00:00:29.080 --> 00:00:32.900
Glad to be back here in the studio
today for more of our Nmap series.

11
00:00:32.900 --> 00:00:34.830
It is entertaining and
fun at the same time, so

12
00:00:34.830 --> 00:00:36.740
hopefully you guys
are getting a lot out of it.

13
00:00:36.740 --> 00:00:37.940
That's my hope, anyway.

14
00:00:37.940 --> 00:00:39.891
That being said, Wes is right.

15
00:00:39.891 --> 00:00:41.238
We are back for a part two.

16
00:00:41.238 --> 00:00:44.632
This isn't our first rodeo, but
we got a little more to learn about.

17
00:00:44.632 --> 00:00:45.180
And actually,

18
00:00:45.180 --> 00:00:48.120
we've got a whole lot more to learn
about if we're gonna be honest with you.

19
00:00:48.120 --> 00:00:51.840
I say we just jump right in,
dive right into the next type of scan.

20
00:00:51.840 --> 00:00:55.980
So that we continue our port
scanning education as it were.

21
00:00:55.980 --> 00:01:00.769
So, the next type of scan that we're gonna
take a look at is the SCTP scan, and

22
00:01:00.769 --> 00:01:04.321
this stands for
Stream Control Transmission Protocol.

23
00:01:04.321 --> 00:01:09.137
And we kinda talked about this and
when I say kinda, I'm talking very quickly

24
00:01:09.137 --> 00:01:13.378
curse over the SCTP when we were
looking at host discovery, right?

25
00:01:13.378 --> 00:01:15.642
There was an option there for SCTP.

26
00:01:15.642 --> 00:01:17.244
And I thought, okay, that's interesting.

27
00:01:17.244 --> 00:01:19.521
It's definitely a new
feature here in Nmap.

28
00:01:19.521 --> 00:01:23.120
And I thought okay, well,
it's not a big deal, I'll just move on.

29
00:01:23.120 --> 00:01:26.556
And I got to port scanning, there was
SCTP again staring me right in the face.

30
00:01:26.556 --> 00:01:28.929
So I thought,
let's take a better look at this thing and

31
00:01:28.929 --> 00:01:30.608
at least understand what's going on.

32
00:01:30.608 --> 00:01:34.543
And even though you might
not have ever heard of SCTP.

33
00:01:34.543 --> 00:01:36.718
And I'm going to be honest with you,
neither did I.

34
00:01:36.718 --> 00:01:41.425
As I searched out what SCTP was,
I found out that most networking

35
00:01:41.425 --> 00:01:45.795
professionals are probably
unaware of SCTP as a protocol.

36
00:01:47.290 --> 00:01:49.130
But they shouldn't, they should be aware.

37
00:01:49.130 --> 00:01:51.670
You guys should definitely learn
as much as you can about SCTP,

38
00:01:51.670 --> 00:01:53.960
it's a very cool protocol.

39
00:01:53.960 --> 00:01:56.510
Things I want you to know about SCTP,

40
00:01:56.510 --> 00:02:00.860
specifically is that it's a Layer 4
protocol, just like TCP is, right?

41
00:02:00.860 --> 00:02:01.698
It's very, very cool.

42
00:02:01.698 --> 00:02:09.540
And you've gotta think of it as
kind of a hybrid of TCP and UDP.

43
00:02:09.540 --> 00:02:14.110
But, for the most part,
it looks mostly like TCP,

44
00:02:14.110 --> 00:02:16.585
but doing basically
the very same function.

45
00:02:16.585 --> 00:02:20.282
We're looking at creating sockets,
making sure data is transmitted and

46
00:02:20.282 --> 00:02:21.840
that the connection was made.

47
00:02:21.840 --> 00:02:26.600
And there was no errors, looks for error
control, all that just like TCP does.

48
00:02:26.600 --> 00:02:31.061
So when you think of SCTP you're
really not far off base if you

49
00:02:31.061 --> 00:02:32.823
just think TCP as well.

50
00:02:32.823 --> 00:02:35.021
>> Now Dan, knowing a little
bit about the transport layer.

51
00:02:35.021 --> 00:02:39.721
I know that the Transmission Control
Protocol is a connection oriented service,

52
00:02:39.721 --> 00:02:41.500
it ensure reliable delivery.

53
00:02:41.500 --> 00:02:45.120
Now, why might I use

00:27:41.092 --> 00:27:44.122
it's not an ACK, it's not an RST, right.

507
00:27:44.122 --> 00:27:44.930
So it's just not gonna respond.

508
00:27:44.930 --> 00:27:49.330
It's gonna say, yeah, I'm an open port but
none of those actually do anything for

509
00:27:49.330 --> 00:27:53.480
me, so there you go, I just won't respond.

510
00:27:53.480 --> 00:27:55.990
See, the closed ports are responding
because they think you are trying to do

511
00:27:55.990 --> 00:28:00.390
something and they let you know,
hey buddy I'm not open for business.

512
00:28:00.390 --> 00:28:01.360
We're closed right now.

513
00:28:01.360 --> 00:28:04.180
I got nothing going on.

514
00:28:04.180 --> 00:28:06.140
There you go.
So it sends that RST.

515
00:28:06.140 --> 00:28:12.700
An open port, though, open port says well
that's not for me, and I need to remain

516
00:28:12.700 --> 00:28:18.620
the way I am it's just the way that it
was created, like I said it's a little

517
00:28:18.620 --> 00:28:22.880
weird way in which it acts is
it just doesn't do anything.

518
00:28:24.410 --> 00:28:26.420
So what happens if the port
is being filtered?

519
00:28:27.510 --> 00:28:31.020
Well, typically,
what happens with filtered ports?

520
00:28:31.020 --> 00:28:35.570
They drop TCP packets that come their
way and that they're filtering, right?

521
00:28:35.570 --> 00:28:37.540
So it won't respond.

522
00:28:37.540 --> 00:28:43.470
So in lies one of the major issues with
using one of these types of scans,

523
00:28:43.470 --> 00:28:44.900
is it's hard to tell whether or

524
00:28:44.900 --> 00:28:48.890
not the portal is open or filtered
because they both respond the same way.

525
00:28:48.890 --> 00:28:50.630
Does that mean it's a useless scan?

526
00:28:50.630 --> 00:28:54.610
No not at all, like we've seen already,

527
00:28:54.610 --> 00:28:59.157
it can at least let you know
if there is a fire rule

528
00:28:59.157 --> 00:29:03.620
maybe that's hiding from
a regular sin scan.

529
00:29:03.620 --> 00:29:05.050
So that's something we missed.

530
00:29:05.050 --> 00:29:07.260
So you can still find use for
these things.

531
00:29:07.260 --> 00:29:10.110
So let's take a look at how
they're actually used and

532
00:29:10.110 --> 00:29:11.900
just kind of run through
them really quickly.

533
00:29:11.900 --> 00:29:13.340
So that you can see them in action.

534
00:29:13.340 --> 00:29:17.780
So let's jump back to my screen and
I'm gonna leave this exact same scan up

535
00:29:17.780 --> 00:29:20.420
because we've already seen sF,
we've seen what it does.

536
00:29:20.420 --> 00:29:26.750
I'm gonna take the scan flags out
of there, and then, just try an sN.

537
00:29:26.750 --> 00:29:29.820
Put in my password here.

538
00:29:31.660 --> 00:29:32.200
There we go.

539
00:29:34.510 --> 00:29:38.440
And, you'll notice,
you get an open filter, right?

540
00:29:38.440 --> 00:29:39.050
Same kind of thing.

541
00:29:39.050 --> 00:29:40.590
It's still responding in the same way.

542
00:29:40.590 --> 00:29:42.170
That's why I say, play around with them.

543
00:29:42.170 --> 00:29:42.820
These are canned.

544
00:29:42.820 --> 00:29:44.780
These are the ones that
are the most popular.

545
00:29:44.780 --> 00:29:47.280
So you just add them to the software and
say okay.

546
00:29:47.280 --> 00:29:49.000
Instead of having to just
scan flags everything,

547
00:29:49.000 --> 00:29:50.960
maybe you want to use one
of most popular ones.

548
00:29:50.960 --> 00:29:53.730
You get null, thin and Christmas.

549
00:29:53.730 --> 00:29:58.170
And one thing I did want to show
you guys is exactly how this looks

550
00:29:58.170 --> 00:29:59.370
as it crosses a network.

551
00:29:59.370 --> 00:30:01.890
So let's fire up Wireshark right.

552
00:30:03.210 --> 00:30:05.010
Let's do a Wireshark.

553
00:30:05.010 --> 00:30:07.960
I know I'm pushing time here,
this should take just a few seconds here.

554
00:30:07.960 --> 00:30:11.470
Let's open up the network and

555
00:30:11.470 --> 00:30:13.910
we will start the capture
which we're already going.

556
00:30:13.910 --> 00:30:21.340
Terminal, let's actually give it an IP
range to keep data down to a minimum.

557
00:30:21.340 --> 00:30:24.561
Dash p, I'll just go here, here we go.

558
00:30:24.561 --> 00:30:29.230
Dash p and we'll say 20 through 25.

559
00:30:29.230 --> 00:30:33.360
There we go, scanning ports, I see
that guy's back there doing something.

560
00:30:33.360 --> 00:30:34.760
That's not the right thing.

561
00:30:34.760 --> 00:30:37.270
There we go.
I'll go ahead and stop the capture.

562
00:30:37.270 --> 00:30:40.990
Now we should have very minimum
data with which to work with.

563
00:30:40.990 --> 00:30:42.970
So this is what we're looking for.

564
00:30:42.970 --> 00:30:45.020
Let's change the source.

565
00:30:45.020 --> 00:30:51.728
So here's my computer,
219.1, talking to .135 and

566
00:30:51.728 --> 00:30:57.810
it's sending a TCP over here,
and you'll notice none.

567
00:30:57.810 --> 00:30:58.812
It doesn't say anything.

568
00:30:58.812 --> 00:31:00.860
There's nothing there, right?

569
00:31:00.860 --> 00:31:04.790
Typically, you'll see something like this,
RST or ACK, what type of flag.

570
00:31:04.790 --> 00:31:06.700
So that must have been my null scan.

571
00:31:06.700 --> 00:31:12.930
So if we look back,
the one which we used was the sN option.

572
00:31:12.930 --> 00:31:15.380
No flags have been set, right?

573
00:31:15.380 --> 00:31:16.950
So, what happens?

574
00:31:16.950 --> 00:31:18.790
What response does it elicit?

575
00:31:20.210 --> 00:31:23.040
I can take a look at some responses here.

576
00:31:23.040 --> 00:31:27.664
It responded with an RST for
port 24 and port 20.

577
00:31:27.664 --> 00:31:30.800
What do we remember about
the way these work?

578
00:31:30.800 --> 00:31:34.410
If you get an RST the port is closed,
right.

579
00:31:34.410 --> 00:31:39.180
So if we look back at our actual
nmap scan, what does it tell me?

580
00:31:39.180 --> 00:31:40.640
Port 20 closed.

581
00:31:40.640 --> 00:31:42.644
Port 24 closed.

582
00:31:42.644 --> 00:31:44.800
Everything is working just right.

583
00:31:44.800 --> 00:31:47.030
Let's look at a Christmas scan,
really quickly again just so

584
00:31:47.030 --> 00:31:48.790
we can see some more coolness.

585
00:31:48.790 --> 00:31:49.370
Whoops.

586
00:31:50.800 --> 00:31:54.454
Start a new.

587
00:31:54.454 --> 00:31:56.377
I'm all over the map with this thing.

588
00:31:56.377 --> 00:32:01.685
There we go, Wireshark back up,
get that network back going,

589
00:32:01.685 --> 00:32:06.302
let's run a Christmas scan just for
the funsies of it.

590
00:32:06.302 --> 00:32:09.889
Take a look at that option,
really quickly.

591
00:32:09.889 --> 00:32:10.938
There we go.

592
00:32:10.938 --> 00:32:13.070
Dash SX for Christmas scan.

593
00:32:14.820 --> 00:32:15.540
There we go.

594
00:32:15.540 --> 00:32:17.940
Same type of response, but

595
00:32:17.940 --> 00:32:21.910
when we look at Wireshark,
you'll notice thin, push and urge.

596
00:32:21.910 --> 00:32:24.220
Let me stop this before it fills up.

597
00:32:24.220 --> 00:32:27.030
Thin, push and urge, and
it's sending to Port 22.

598
00:32:27.030 --> 00:32:31.590
We get the responses, the RSTs,
the other are not responding at all

599
00:32:31.590 --> 00:32:36.580
letting us know the port is open, and
it bypassed our firewall as well because,

600
00:32:36.580 --> 00:32:41.570
look at this,
port 23 is showing open filtered,

601
00:32:41.570 --> 00:32:46.560
even though we're fire-walling
that from a typical sim type scan.

602
00:32:46.560 --> 00:32:47.290
Not gonna show up.

603
00:32:47.290 --> 00:32:49.870
If I do a sim scan, if I just sudo mmap.

604
00:32:51.262 --> 00:32:54.731
Just so you guys know that I'm
not cheating you here, -sS,

605
00:32:54.731 --> 00:32:57.610
--send-ip 192.168.219 at 35.

606
00:32:57.610 --> 00:33:05.283
You know it's all good in the hood.

607
00:33:05.283 --> 00:33:07.735
Look at that, not showing up.

608
00:33:07.735 --> 00:33:10.410
Port 22 straight to 25.

609
00:33:10.410 --> 00:33:13.250
So doing a great job here.

610
00:33:13.250 --> 00:33:19.240
We can use the different types of
advantages using the send flags.

611
00:33:19.240 --> 00:33:23.640
That we have, and are available,
to bypass around routers.

612
00:33:23.640 --> 00:33:26.840
Now, if you've got a modern IDS or
IPS, this isn't going to help you,

613
00:33:26.840 --> 00:33:28.030
they'll detect this type of thing.

614
00:33:28.030 --> 00:33:29.410
It's very common.

615
00:33:29.410 --> 00:33:31.420
Even though it's still fast, it's great,

616
00:33:31.420 --> 00:33:34.060
it's even more stealthy
than a typical SYN scan.

617
00:33:34.060 --> 00:33:36.490
Obviously it's getting
around firewalls that way.

618
00:33:36.490 --> 00:33:42.200
But modern IDSs or state firewalls will
probably still be able detect this.

619
00:33:42.200 --> 00:33:43.280
That doesn't mean you don't use it.

620
00:33:43.280 --> 00:33:46.340
It just means that you
gotta be aware of that, and

621
00:33:46.340 --> 00:33:51.000
that it might not avail you of anymore
information than it's suppose to scan.

622
00:33:51.000 --> 00:33:51.600
It's quick.

623
00:33:51.600 --> 00:33:52.430
It's fast.

624
00:33:52.430 --> 00:33:53.730
And it gets around firewalls.

625
00:33:53.730 --> 00:33:55.330
Use it when it's appropriate.

626
00:33:55.330 --> 00:33:58.430
And play around with it and
see what kinda cool responses you can get.

627
00:33:58.430 --> 00:34:03.210
But that, my friends, is part two of
port scanning wrapped up in a ball.

628
00:34:03.210 --> 00:34:05.590
I know it was a lot and
we do have more to go through.

629
00:34:05.590 --> 00:34:08.760
As my voice is now getting hoarse,
sounds very awesome.

630
00:34:08.760 --> 00:34:12.230
But that's it, Wes, and
we got part three coming.

631
00:34:12.230 --> 00:34:14.260
>> All right, well, you know
that's a lot of great information,

632
00:34:14.260 --> 00:34:16.950
a lot of fun information too, and
it's good when you know how to dig

633
00:34:16.950 --> 00:34:19.670
just a little bit deeper to
find those systems out there.

634
00:34:19.670 --> 00:34:22.060
Like you said, Dan, we are coming
to the end of another episode,

635
00:34:22.060 --> 00:34:24.365
do you have anything else you would
like to put into this episode?

636
00:34:24.365 --> 00:34:25.725
We're going to save that for the trilogy.

637
00:34:25.725 --> 00:34:30.775
>> No no and one last thing I'll
tell you is that open filter right.

638
00:34:30.775 --> 00:34:33.895
If you combine a regular SIN scan and

639
00:34:33.895 --> 00:34:38.600
then a FIN scan and
then maybe another type of scan and

640
00:34:38.600 --> 00:34:43.090
you're seeing filtered,
open filtered, open filtered.

641
00:34:43.090 --> 00:34:46.040
Well, the one comment is
that everything is filtered.

642
00:34:47.170 --> 00:34:51.170
It's probably a good deduction that,
that's a filtered port.

643
00:34:51.170 --> 00:34:53.138
So use them in conjunction
with each other.

644
00:34:53.138 --> 00:34:56.920
Just because you're seeing open filter and
you can't tell whether or not it's opened

645
00:34:56.920 --> 00:35:01.360
or filtered doesn't mean you can't deduce
whether or not something is open filtered.

646
00:35:01.360 --> 00:35:03.240
Just keep that in mind
as you do your scan.

647
00:35:03.240 --> 00:35:07.630
We will have a lot of fun here but we'll
save the rest of it for the next part.

648
00:35:07.630 --> 00:35:08.270
>> Absolutely.

649
00:35:08.270 --> 00:35:10.820
Well, we appreciate you being
in the studios with us and

650
00:35:10.820 --> 00:35:12.270
look forward to seeing you in our Part 3.

651
00:35:12.270 --> 00:35:14.590
And we look forward to seeing
you guys in that Part 3.

652
00:35:14.590 --> 00:35:17.030
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

653
00:35:17.030 --> 00:35:18.020
>> And I'm Daniel Lowrie.

654
00:35:18.020 --> 00:35:21.935
>> And we'll see you next time.

655
00:35:21.935 --> 00:35:28.060
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike continue their look at types of port scanning. They explain and demonstrate how to perform an ACK scan to determine if a firewall is stateful or stateless. They also discuss Windows scans, Maimon scans, and an SCTP Cookie scan.
episodes.title: Port Scanning Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.154 --> 00:00:15.518
Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.518 --> 00:00:19.080
I'm your host Mike Rodrick and
today we're doing our Nmap series.

4
00:00:19.080 --> 00:00:22.240
Specifically, in this episode,
we're gonna doing port scanning.

5
00:00:22.240 --> 00:00:25.174
Now we've already had a couple episodes
that are dealing with port scanning and

6
00:00:25.174 --> 00:00:26.503
we've got more types of scan to do.

7
00:00:26.503 --> 00:00:30.272
And who better to help guide us through
the wonderful world of scanning than Mr.

8
00:00:30.272 --> 00:00:31.066
Daniel Lowrie.

9
00:00:31.066 --> 00:00:31.800
How are you doing, Dan?

10
00:00:31.800 --> 00:00:35.375
>> Mike, I'm doing fantastic,
I love the Nmap, I love this.

11
00:00:35.375 --> 00:00:39.170
And you're no slouch yourself, so I'm kind
of glad to have you here with me today.

12
00:00:39.170 --> 00:00:42.966
Yes, Mike is correct, we have done
a couple of episodes on port scanning.

13
00:00:42.966 --> 00:00:45.460
You're like wow,
how do you go through two episodes and

14
00:00:45.460 --> 00:00:46.950
now you're onto a third
with port scanning?

15
00:00:46.950 --> 00:00:49.914
Well, there's a lot that this
lovely little tool can do, and

16
00:00:49.914 --> 00:00:52.884
I kinda warned you about that
back when we started the series.

17
00:00:52.884 --> 00:00:56.294
So hopefully this is no surprise
that we're still continuing on port

18
00:00:56.294 --> 00:00:57.480
scanning types.

19
00:00:57.480 --> 00:00:58.950
But it is good to know
because there are so

20
00:00:58.950 --> 00:01:02.425
many different ways that
Nmap is helpful to us.

21
00:01:02.425 --> 00:01:06.032
In either disseminating the different
computers that are on our network,

22
00:01:06.032 --> 00:01:08.510
or if we're trying to do a good scan, and

23
00:01:08.510 --> 00:01:11.280
maybe a certain scan will work
better over another scan.

24
00:01:11.280 --> 00:01:15.222
So none of these are the way to do it,
they're just ways to do it.

25
00:01:15.222 --> 00:01:18.628
And you use the right application for
whatever your environment calls for.

26
00:01:18.628 --> 00:01:21.868
So that's where we're trying to work you
through all these multiple different types

27
00:01:21.868 --> 00:01:22.457
of port scans.

28
00:01:22.457 --> 00:01:25.939
>> So it really comes down to different
environments, different operating systems

29
00:01:25.939 --> 00:01:28.673
respond differently to different
types of packets we send out.

30
00:01:28.673 --> 00:01:32.458
So all these different scans are basically
using a different flag set in the packet,

31
00:01:32.458 --> 00:01:35.815
or a different combination of flags to
hopefully give us the results we're

32
00:01:35.815 --> 00:01:36.470
looking for.

33
00:01:36.470 --> 00:01:37.570
>> That is exactly right.

34
00:01:37.570 --> 00:01:40.010
It's the whole purpose of us walking
you through each one of them.

35
00:01:40.010 --> 00:01:42.790
Plus, we want you to be
very well versed and

36
00:01:42.790 --> 00:01:45.960
understand what is happening
during each one of the scans.

37
00:01:45.960 --> 00:01:47.170
That way if something goes wrong,

38
00:01:47.170 --> 00:01:49.600
you get an output that you're not,
hm, that doesn't look right.

39
00:01:49.600 --> 00:01:50.940
Why is this not working?

40
00:01:50.940 --> 00:01:54.050
Well, if you understand how the scan
works, you can try to figure out

41
00:01:54.050 --> 00:01:56.750
why it's not giving you the results
you might be looking for.

42
00:01:56.750 --> 00:01:58.110
So that's why I wanna give you a nice,

43
00:01:58.110 --> 00:02:01.030
good, in depth look at
each one of these scans.

44
00:02:01.030 --> 00:02:04.440
That being said,
let's move on to our next type of scan and

45
00:02:04.440 --> 00:02:05.780
this is an interesting scan.

46
00:02:05.780 --> 00:02:11.200
It's not so
much of a port scan as it is a way to

47
00:02:11.200 --> 00:02:14.900
elucidate, if I can use that term [LAUGH],
firewall rules.

48
00:02:14.900 --> 00:02:17.412
>> Only if you define it for
us after you use it, right?

49
00:02:17.412 --> 00:02:20.747
>> [LAUGH] That's right,
let's go to dictionary.com real quick and.

50
00:02:20.747 --> 00:02:24.441
Basically, it just means that we can know
and understand what we're looking for

51
00:02:24.441 --> 00:02:26.830
specifically, and that is firewall rules.

52
00:02:26.830 --> 00:02:29.760
Cuz a lot of times,
what are we doing as admins, right?

53
00:02:29.760 --> 00:02:32.490
We're trying to stop people
that are using Nmap for

54
00:02:32.490 --> 00:02:35.940
nefarious purposes,
from discerning things on our network.

55
00:02:35.940 --> 00:02:38.900
We don't want them to know
what services we're running.

56
00:02:38.900 --> 00:02:41.589
Even if we are,
we'll like to hide that if we can or

57
00:02:41.589 --> 00:02:43.456
just block them straight from it.

58
00:02:43.456 --> 00:02:47.270
And firewalls tend to be our
go-to form of making that happen.

59
00:02:47.270 --> 00:02:51.090
Obviously, multiple different types of
firewalls are out there, benders and

60
00:02:51.090 --> 00:02:53.490
the ways that they work,
the instructions sets, all that.

61
00:02:53.490 --> 00:02:58.018
So you're gonna have to basically work
with whatever firewall it is you're

62
00:02:58.018 --> 00:03:04.040
implementing, to know how to make it
basically stop these scans from working.

63
00:03:04.040 --> 00:03:05.970
And sometimes you can,
sometimes you can't,

64
00:03:05.970 --> 00:03:09.010
but that is what we're gonna
try to do today with this scan.

65
00:03:09.010 --> 00:03:13.034
The scan is called the ACK scan,
the E-A, the A-E, yeah.

66
00:03:13.034 --> 00:03:15.530
>> [LAUGH]
>> A-C-K, ACK, not ECK, ACK,

67
00:03:15.530 --> 00:03:17.961
that is the scan we're talking about.

68
00:03:17.961 --> 00:03:23.779
Because it uses the ACK flag in the TCP
packet to basically bypass firewalls and

69
00:03:23.779 --> 00:03:26.150
find out is being filtered.

70
00:03:26.150 --> 00:03:28.829
That being said, using the ACK scan,

71
00:03:28.829 --> 00:03:32.439
you cannot discern what is closed or
open, right.

72
00:03:32.439 --> 00:03:35.340
It's not what the scan is for, that's what
we have the other types of scans for.

73
00:03:35.340 --> 00:03:37.610
And other scans that we're gonna see.

74
00:03:37.610 --> 00:03:42.030
This type of scan is specifically for
mapping out firewall rules.

75
00:03:42.030 --> 00:03:45.930
I think that is the verbiage used
inside of the documentation when you do

76
00:03:45.930 --> 00:03:49.650
the manual, or
the Nmap inside of your terminal.

77
00:03:49.650 --> 00:03:51.670
So when you look at that,
that's what we're trying to do.

78
00:03:51.670 --> 00:03:54.964
We're trying to map out what is

00:12:31.590 --> 00:12:34.610
>> Well let's see, you're gonna start

00:12:34.610 --> 00:12:37.240

wants to communicate with.

00:12:37.240 --> 00:12:40.740
Should respond with a sind ack,
so acknowledging that send

00:12:40.740 --> 00:12:43.070
packet that is that first

00:12:43.070 --> 00:12:46.090
And then a final acknowledgment
back from the original sender

238
00:12:46.090 --> 00:12:49.238
to acknowledge the send packet
that the receiver had sent.

00:12:49.238 --> 00:12:49.860

00:12:49.860 --> 00:12:51.650
It is our acknowledgment flag, right.

241
00:12:51.650 --> 00:12:54.180
It's saying that I've acknowledged

00:12:54.180 --> 00:12:56.230

00:12:56.230 --> 00:12:59.923
With the second part of the hand shake

00:12:59.923 --> 00:13:01.540
an ack, sets both of those flags.

00:13:01.540 --> 00:13:04.270
So there is an ack there,

00:13:04.270 --> 00:13:06.280
The only time an ack is alone,
well at least for our intents and

00:13:06.280 --> 00:13:10.100

is being established.

248
00:13:10.100 --> 00:13:13.150

00:13:13.150 --> 00:13:16.160
And then that connection is built and
you can start transferring data.

00:13:16.160 --> 00:13:21.130

00:13:21.130 --> 00:13:24.120
That's why this works, right,

But these ports weren't because

541
00:27:06.200 --> 00:27:08.210
If you send that out and

542
00:27:08.210 --> 00:27:13.110
it says 1000 ports are filtered,
you're probably working with a stateful

543
00:27:13.110 --> 00:27:17.700
firewall because none of the ACKs are
making its way past the firewall rules.

544
00:27:17.700 --> 00:27:21.880
It could just be a guy that's
gone buck wild with ACL's and

545
00:27:21.880 --> 00:27:24.218
has written a rule for every possible.

546
00:27:24.218 --> 00:27:28.480
But not probable, but could happen.

547
00:27:28.480 --> 00:27:30.440
It might happen, you could see that.

548
00:27:30.440 --> 00:27:35.176
So I'm saying it's not 100%, you have to
be discerning, you have to really look at

549
00:27:35.176 --> 00:27:39.350
the data that's coming back and
figure out what it's trying to tell you.

550
00:27:39.350 --> 00:27:40.470
But that's how you're gonna do it.

551
00:27:40.470 --> 00:27:44.240
If the port responds you get some
unfiltered and some filtered,

552
00:27:44.240 --> 00:27:46.270
you're probably working
with a stateless firewall.

553
00:27:46.270 --> 00:27:49.548
If you get all filtered, you're probably
working with a stateful firewall.

554
00:27:49.548 --> 00:27:52.460
It's basically all you
need to know about that.

555
00:27:52.460 --> 00:27:55.916
Let me see if there's anything else
I wanted you guys to know when

556
00:27:55.916 --> 00:27:56.882
it comes to this.

557
00:27:56.882 --> 00:28:00.396
No response, obviously it's letting you
know it's filtered because it's dropping

558
00:28:00.396 --> 00:28:00.981
the packets.

559
00:28:00.981 --> 00:28:08.740
If you get ICMP;errors, the type
III code 013 2 and 3, 9, 10 and 13.

560
00:28:08.740 --> 00:28:12.120
You get those, that's a rejection.

561
00:28:12.120 --> 00:28:15.392
It's saying I'm filtering stuff,
you're getting those ICP errors.

562
00:28:15.392 --> 00:28:17.660
So you're gonna see filter.

563
00:28:17.660 --> 00:28:19.920
That's basically the ACK
scan wrapped up in a ball.

564
00:28:19.920 --> 00:28:23.150
I know we got a little bit of time left,
there are a few other scans I wanna

565
00:28:23.150 --> 00:28:26.650
quickly run through, and I'm not doing you
a disservice because they're basically

566
00:28:26.650 --> 00:28:30.770
the ACK scan with a little modifier,
little twist to how they work.

567
00:28:32.110 --> 00:28:35.440
One of them is the Windows scan,
jump to my terminal quickly.

568
00:28:35.440 --> 00:28:40.975
I'm gonna clear screen windows
scan is sudo nmap -sw and

569
00:28:40.975 --> 00:28:46.756
then your target 192.168.219.135 boom!

570
00:28:46.756 --> 00:28:47.402
Fire it off.

571
00:28:49.865 --> 00:28:53.900
There we go and
it looks just like an ACK scan.

572
00:28:53.900 --> 00:28:54.820
It does, right?

573
00:28:54.820 --> 00:28:57.290
It just does things
a little bit differently.

574
00:28:57.290 --> 00:29:00.840
The Windows scan can actually determine,

575
00:29:00.840 --> 00:29:05.740
in some cases, whether or not a port is
open or closed by the way it responds.

576
00:29:05.740 --> 00:29:10.420
Because of the window field
inside of the packet.

577
00:29:10.420 --> 00:29:13.000
So if you look at the packet like
we do with Wireshark just a minute

578
00:29:13.000 --> 00:29:17.330
ago where we saw the flags, there's also
another place there for the window size.

579
00:29:17.330 --> 00:29:22.140
If the window field has a positive size,
then usually the port is open.

580
00:29:22.140 --> 00:29:23.569
That's typical, it's just RFC compliance.

581
00:29:24.660 --> 00:29:29.440
If the window has a field size of 0,
then the port is usually closed.

582
00:29:29.440 --> 00:29:33.890
Now, the only problem with this
is this not a very reliable scan.

583
00:29:33.890 --> 00:29:35.260
When it works, it's awesome, all right?

584
00:29:35.260 --> 00:29:37.590
Cuz it tells you whether
the ports are opened or closed.

585
00:29:37.590 --> 00:29:39.360
And you get firewall rules.

586
00:29:39.360 --> 00:29:43.913
Sweet, awesome stuff right, but
it's just not very, very reliable.

587
00:29:43.913 --> 00:29:46.250
You are not gonna see this
work on a ton of machines.

588
00:29:46.250 --> 00:29:50.225
Does that mean you just toss it in a bin
and say I don't even know why that is in

589
00:29:50.225 --> 00:29:54.870
nmap, no because there is gonna be
those times that this is the thing

590
00:29:54.870 --> 00:29:58.580
that gets you the data you are looking for
when the other scans don't.

591
00:29:58.580 --> 00:30:01.460
So it doesn't mean you discard it,
it just means that, when you run it,

592
00:30:01.460 --> 00:30:02.550
expect it to fail or

593
00:30:02.550 --> 00:30:06.270
not gives you back much information
other than what you've already gotten.

594
00:30:06.270 --> 00:30:08.420
If you do hit the money load though,

595
00:30:08.420 --> 00:30:10.750
you're on easy street because
it's done what you want it to do.

596
00:30:10.750 --> 00:30:14.355
It's tell you whether or
not ports are open or closed.

597
00:30:14.355 --> 00:30:17.045
Another one is the Maimon scan.

598
00:30:17.045 --> 00:30:18.600
Yeah, it's a mouth full, right?

599
00:30:18.600 --> 00:30:19.625
>> [LAUGH]
>> Let's go

600
00:30:19.625 --> 00:30:20.985
back to the terminal here really quick.

601
00:30:20.985 --> 00:30:22.355
We'll run that scan.

602
00:30:22.355 --> 00:30:25.601
So I'm just bringing back the same scan I
just run cuz we're just gonna change this

603
00:30:25.601 --> 00:30:26.412
whole option here.

604
00:30:26.412 --> 00:30:32.185
Changing that to sM,
that's the Maimon scan.

605
00:30:32.185 --> 00:30:34.537
Again, looks just like ACK.

606
00:30:34.537 --> 00:30:36.410
Well what's its big hairy deal?

607
00:30:36.410 --> 00:30:42.010
It works kind of like a FIN,
or a NULL, or a XMAS scan.

608
00:30:42.010 --> 00:30:47.560
It sets some flags, and
it's setting the FIN and ACK flags.

609
00:30:47.560 --> 00:30:53.170
It says that the target should respond
with an RST if the port is open or

610
00:30:53.170 --> 00:30:54.010
closed, right?

611
00:30:54.010 --> 00:30:55.910
Kind of like what we talked about before.

612
00:30:55.910 --> 00:30:59.333
This guy named Ural Maimon or
Mimen, whatever his name is,

613
00:30:59.333 --> 00:31:02.760
realized that a lot of BSD
systems responded in this way.

614
00:31:02.760 --> 00:31:04.270
If the port was open and closed.

615
00:31:04.270 --> 00:31:09.240
Instead of doing the traditional
version of how the ACK works.

616
00:31:09.240 --> 00:31:13.830
If you send the FIN ACK,
you can get some response out of it.

617
00:31:13.830 --> 00:31:18.120
So again another one of those scans
you're probably not gonna use a ton, but

618
00:31:18.120 --> 00:31:23.188
if you're working on a heavily
BSD operating system environment.

619
00:31:23.188 --> 00:31:26.700
You might wanna throw that at the, and
the kitchen sink at it from time to time.

620
00:31:26.700 --> 00:31:29.100
See maybe you'll get exactly
what you're looking for.

621
00:31:29.100 --> 00:31:36.112
And the very last scan we have to talk
about is the SCTP cookie echo scan.

622
00:31:36.112 --> 00:31:39.919
We've talked about SCTP in
previous episodes as well.

623
00:31:39.919 --> 00:31:45.767
Very cool protocol, very TCP like but
better really to be honest with you.

624
00:31:45.767 --> 00:31:49.392
It's just not intrenched yet
because TCP is every stinking where.

625
00:31:49.392 --> 00:31:55.516
But basically what you wanna know about
this is the switch is S capital Z.

626
00:31:55.516 --> 00:31:59.894
I'm not gonna trouble you with showing it
on the screen because I am not running

627
00:31:59.894 --> 00:32:01.163
an SCTP environment.

628
00:32:01.163 --> 00:32:03.290
So it's not really gonna
do a whole lot for me.

629
00:32:03.290 --> 00:32:04.360
You can run it.

630
00:32:04.360 --> 00:32:06.770
Even if you're not running
SCTP it will still run, but

631
00:32:06.770 --> 00:32:09.280
I don't know what kind of
output you'll get for that.

632
00:32:09.280 --> 00:32:15.080
But if you are running SCTP this is
that when you send a SCTP packet,

633
00:32:15.080 --> 00:32:20.060
there's a little cookie area that's
involved inside of that packet, right.

634
00:32:20.060 --> 00:32:22.830
And it has an echo that
goes along with it.

635
00:32:22.830 --> 00:32:27.240
If you send that echo,
what it will do is, well,

636
00:32:27.240 --> 00:32:31.010
let me grab my notes here,
make sure I'm telling you correctly.

637
00:32:31.010 --> 00:32:34.659
What will happen is,
if the port receives it,

638
00:32:34.659 --> 00:32:38.597
it should either send an abort or
something else.

639
00:32:38.597 --> 00:32:42.770
What was the other thing?

640
00:32:42.770 --> 00:32:45.860
The abort shows that it's closed,
and then the echo.

641
00:32:45.860 --> 00:32:47.350
The echo was what shows that it's open.

642
00:32:47.350 --> 00:32:49.740
So if you send that cookie,
that SCTP cookie,

643
00:32:49.740 --> 00:32:52.820
I'm sorry that's where I was getting
confused, my mind was twisting around.

644
00:32:52.820 --> 00:32:55.670
The SCT echo comes back,
you know the port is open.

645
00:32:55.670 --> 00:32:59.780
If you get the abort,
it's kinda like RST and SYN-ACK, right.

646
00:32:59.780 --> 00:33:01.140
Just for it's protocol.

647
00:33:01.140 --> 00:33:05.030
It's the same type of idea, right.

648
00:33:05.030 --> 00:33:07.500
You get one,
you know a thing is happening.

649
00:33:07.500 --> 00:33:10.510
You get the other, it's just, I don't
know what you're doing, I'm not open for

650
00:33:10.510 --> 00:33:12.590
business so abort.

651
00:33:12.590 --> 00:33:14.650
Pull the rip cord, I'm out,
jump out the plane.

652
00:33:14.650 --> 00:33:16.250
Be done with it.

653
00:33:16.250 --> 00:33:18.732
The advantages are that it
is more stealthy obviously.

654
00:33:18.732 --> 00:33:23.318
It can get past non-stateful firewalls,
right.

655
00:33:23.318 --> 00:33:25.730
We've seen how that kind of action works.

656
00:33:25.730 --> 00:33:29.960
Disadvantages are it's still
detectable by IDS and IPSs.

657
00:33:29.960 --> 00:33:34.660
And you can't tell the difference
between open and filtered ports, so

658
00:33:34.660 --> 00:33:40.316
you typically the see the output
state as open pipe filtered,

659
00:33:40.316 --> 00:33:43.420
cuz I don't know if it's open or filter,
so am just gonna say open filter.

660
00:33:43.420 --> 00:33:45.100
All right, that's what it's gonna do.

661
00:33:45.100 --> 00:33:46.110
>> It's not closed.

662
00:33:46.110 --> 00:33:47.030
>> Yeah, it's not closed.

663
00:33:47.030 --> 00:33:49.050
We know that, it's not closed.

664
00:33:49.050 --> 00:33:53.140
But it is open or filtered and
the more scans you throw at it, and

665
00:33:53.140 --> 00:33:57.680
you start seeing a consistency,
if it's consistently showing up as

666
00:33:57.680 --> 00:34:00.990
more filtered than open, you probably
are working with a filtered port.

667
00:34:00.990 --> 00:34:04.310
You're seeing open, open filter open,
it's probably open.

668
00:34:04.310 --> 00:34:07.835
So you just gotta use a little
discernment, but that's our scans.

669
00:34:07.835 --> 00:34:08.815
That's port scanning.

670
00:34:08.815 --> 00:34:14.255
We have completed the standard
bevy of port scans.

671
00:34:14.255 --> 00:34:16.185
That wraps this up.

672
00:34:16.185 --> 00:34:18.651
With the next episodes, we'll get into
a little more advanced port scanning.

673
00:34:18.651 --> 00:34:20.412
You might think,
I don't know that sounded advanced, but

674
00:34:20.412 --> 00:34:22.682
it's not, that's standard stuff,
but we'll get into more.

675
00:34:22.682 --> 00:34:23.572
It's actually really cool,

676
00:34:23.572 --> 00:34:26.072
I'm looking forward for
us to be doing the next couple of shows.

677
00:34:26.072 --> 00:34:27.667
>> Nice.
>> That's all I got for us today, Mike.

678
00:34:27.667 --> 00:34:30.192
>> All right, fantastic,
wasn't it, ladies and gentlemen?

679
00:34:30.192 --> 00:34:33.890
I mean really good look at as we've
been doing these last few videos,

680
00:34:33.890 --> 00:34:35.118
looking at these port scans.

681
00:34:35.118 --> 00:34:38.960
Here, we get to take a close up look at
the ACK scan, how it's working underneath

682
00:34:38.960 --> 00:34:41.870
the hood, got to capture some
of that traffic and see it.

683
00:34:41.870 --> 00:34:45.670
And really, Daniel did a great job there,
explaining the results, what you get back.

684
00:34:45.670 --> 00:34:47.590
How do I interpret what I'm getting back?

685
00:34:47.590 --> 00:34:48.410
Cuz that's what it's all about.

686
00:34:48.410 --> 00:34:52.280
We can run these scans, but if we can't
figure out what their resulting data means

687
00:34:52.280 --> 00:34:54.570
to us, doesn't do a lot of good,
so we thank you for that.

688
00:34:54.570 --> 00:34:58.260
And we also got a good look at a couple
alternative ACK scans if you will, right.

689
00:34:58.260 --> 00:35:02.710
We got that Windows scan in there, we
got that scan in there, and then one for

690
00:35:02.710 --> 00:35:06.770
a new protocol that we might or might not
see on a network, but another good one to

691
00:35:06.770 --> 00:35:13.950
have in the tool bag just in case is
that SCTP protocol scan capability.

692
00:35:13.950 --> 00:35:15.730
So fantastic, we appreciate that, Daniel.

693
00:35:15.730 --> 00:35:16.370
>> No problem.

694
00:35:16.370 --> 00:35:18.110
>> Hope everybody out
there enjoyed watching.

695
00:35:18.110 --> 00:35:21.060
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Mike Rodrick.

696
00:35:21.060 --> 00:35:21.760
>> I'm Daniel Lowrie.

697
00:35:21.760 --> 00:35:22.915
>> And we'll see you next time.

698
00:35:22.915 --> 00:35:32.380

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike discuss some advanced port scanning techniques. In particular, they focus on an IP ID idle scan, explaining how it works. Then they demonstrate an IP ID Idle scan, and examine the output.
episodes.title: Advanced Port Scanning IP ID Idle Scan

We're gonna be getting into some

And of course, back with me again is

We've moved on from the typical

And now we're gonna get

We're gonna spend

It might not go full, maybe cuz I like

But it's all gonna be about the IP ID
idle scan, which is a mouthful to say.

23

It doesn't look like much on paper,
it's just a little short ip id idle scans,

24
00:01:15.790 --> 00:01:19.170
very short, but
to say that is a bit of a mouthful.

25
00:01:19.170 --> 00:01:22.492
What is this IP ID idle,
see it's even harder to say.

26
00:01:22.492 --> 00:01:26.050
IP ID idle scan of which you speak,

00:01:26.050 --> 00:01:26.840
Well, I'm glad you did,

because otherwise you should probably be

00:01:31.858 --> 00:01:36.960
It is a very, very sneaky scan and

the great thing about this is that

00:01:42.264 --> 00:01:47.555
system to be our middle man if you

32

Yeah, so we're gonna take a look at

33
00:01:52.635 --> 00:01:56.090
We're gonna start off with just I

34

What are we talking about?

00:01:57.160 --> 00:01:57.720
How do you mean?

36
00:01:57.720 --> 00:02:02.710
How do I get these other players to

37

Do I install Nmap?

38
00:02:04.000 --> 00:02:05.720
What do I do, right?

39
00:02:05.720 --> 00:02:07.540
Very simple, simple thing.

40
00:02:07.540 --> 00:02:11.090
It's the fact that the way
some machines work,

41
00:02:11.090 --> 00:02:12.900
we're gonna exploit how that happens.

42
00:02:12.900 --> 00:02:14.540
That's what we're gonna take a look at.

43

So where should we start?

44

First thing, the terminology I want to use

00:02:19.870 --> 00:02:24.390
is it does what we like to say

46
00:02:24.390 --> 00:02:29.350
And we say that it's blind because we

47
00:02:29.350 --> 00:02:32.610
We're having that intermediate do it for
us,

48
00:02:32.610 --> 00:02:35.920
we're having our little proxy
guy kind of do this game first.

49
00:02:35.920 --> 00:02:41.520
So we don't actually touch the machine,

50
00:02:41.520 --> 00:02:42.536
But for the most part, we don't.

51
00:02:42.536 --> 00:02:43.690
>> Kind of indirectly.

52
00:02:43.690 --> 00:02:46.500
>> Yes, very indirectly,
very, very indirectly.

53
00:02:46.500 --> 00:02:51.060
Only in certain ways, and when we do

54
00:02:52.110 --> 00:02:55.390
we pretend that we're not us, yeah, right.

55
00:02:55.390 --> 00:02:57.650
It's gonna be really cool,
a lot of fun with that.

56
00:02:57.650 --> 00:02:58.910
Let's see here.

57
00:02:58.910 --> 00:03:05.370
What we do is like I said, we use an

58
00:03:05.370 --> 00:03:06.395
It's kind of a fun name, right?

59
00:03:06.395 --> 00:03:10.655
We got zombies in our network

60
00:03:10.655 --> 00:03:15.245
And when we do that, when we implement
that zombie to do that scan,

61
00:03:15.245 --> 00:03:16.905
what does that do for us?

62
00:03:16.905 --> 00:03:19.435
Why would we want to
implement the service scan?

63
00:03:19.435 --> 00:03:21.095
If we really need to be sneaky and

64
00:03:21.095 --> 00:03:25.950
we don't want it showing up
in things like IDS or IPS.

65
00:03:25.950 --> 00:03:29.470
That we were doing the scanning.

00:27:29.710 --> 00:27:33.500
So let's do that, we've got our good
zombie, we know what our target is,

532
00:27:33.500 --> 00:27:35.320
we're ready to launch the attack.

533
00:27:35.320 --> 00:27:42.120
So, we will do it,
we will say sudo mf, obviously, NMAP.

534
00:27:42.120 --> 00:27:44.833
And we'll say -Pn.

535
00:27:44.833 --> 00:27:48.360
And this, if you remember, stops pings.

536
00:27:48.360 --> 00:27:52.240
We don't wanna send pings because
we're trying to be stealthy here.

537
00:27:52.240 --> 00:27:54.350
We don't want it to reach out and

538
00:27:54.350 --> 00:27:56.850
talk to people we don't want
it to reach out and talk to.

539
00:27:56.850 --> 00:27:59.590
So I just say just don't ping,
don't worry about that.

540
00:27:59.590 --> 00:28:03.828
I'm gonna give me some verbosity as well,
cuz I like verbosity.

541
00:28:03.828 --> 00:28:08.100
And then -si

542
00:28:08.100 --> 00:28:12.770
is the IP ID idle scan flag or
switch for NMAP.

543
00:28:12.770 --> 00:28:16.518
First thing we're gonna give
it is our zombie, all right?

544
00:28:16.518 --> 00:28:24.720
So that's 192.16.8.209.138, and
we are also gonna give it a port

545
00:28:24.720 --> 00:28:29.600
which is, let's do 135,
I think 135 was open, right Mike?

546
00:28:29.600 --> 00:28:30.580
>> 135?
It should be.

547
00:28:30.580 --> 00:28:34.940
>> Alright, so 135 is open,
that's the port I'm gonna choose, and

548
00:28:34.940 --> 00:28:37.175
then I gotta give it the actual target.

549
00:28:37.175 --> 00:28:44.770
192.16.8.219.135, and
I think we are ready to rock and roll.

550
00:28:44.770 --> 00:28:45.920
Hit return.

551
00:28:45.920 --> 00:28:46.900
Off it goes.

552
00:28:46.900 --> 00:28:51.740
I like to give the verbosity because it
shows us a lot that's happening here.

553
00:28:51.740 --> 00:28:55.790
Look so it says scanning 135 and

554
00:28:55.790 --> 00:28:58.810
initiating IP idle scan
against metaexploitable.

555
00:28:58.810 --> 00:29:02.350
At this time, IP scan using zombie and

556
00:29:02.350 --> 00:29:05.060
then there's the IP address
of the zombie host.

557
00:29:05.060 --> 00:29:09.060
And even the port number that we used
because the class is incremental.

558
00:29:09.060 --> 00:29:13.230
Its all working,
it's discovering open ports, and

559
00:29:13.230 --> 00:29:16.900
if that metaexploitable machine
is running any kind of logging,

560
00:29:16.900 --> 00:29:21.700
any kind of even just standard TCP
logging, what connections have I made?

561
00:29:21.700 --> 00:29:25.230
And people wanna look at that output,
they could go in and see that.

562
00:29:25.230 --> 00:29:31.240
But it wouldn't be coming from us because
it is coming from that guy right there.

563
00:29:31.240 --> 00:29:32.000
Very cool stuff.

564
00:29:32.000 --> 00:29:36.840
As soon as this is done, it should,
usually this scan on a network like ours,

565
00:29:36.840 --> 00:29:38.650
just takes about a minute,
minute and a half.

566
00:29:38.650 --> 00:29:39.900
Not too terribly long.

567
00:29:39.900 --> 00:29:43.266
Gives me enough time to sip
my lovely beverage from this

568
00:29:43.266 --> 00:29:45.711
wonderful IT Pro TV glass service cup.

569
00:29:45.711 --> 00:29:50.790
>> [LAUGH] It is a really neat concept
though, the fact that we are able

570
00:29:50.790 --> 00:29:55.480
to perform a scan against a target machine
without actually contacting the target.

571
00:29:55.480 --> 00:30:02.010
Like you said, avoid any type of login,
hopefully, being detected.

572
00:30:02.010 --> 00:30:02.840
And as you said,

573
00:30:02.840 --> 00:30:07.010
the zombie is gonna be the one that
is gonna show up in log files.

574
00:30:07.010 --> 00:30:08.350
>> Right.
>> And the other thing is too,

575
00:30:08.350 --> 00:30:12.240
it might be where we can't, as you were
saying, can't get directly to that node

576
00:30:12.240 --> 00:30:16.640
that we're trying to scan because of
firewall rules blocking our IP range,

577
00:30:16.640 --> 00:30:19.820
you know that kind of traffic coming
from the outside for example.

578
00:30:19.820 --> 00:30:23.740
We can compromise our web server, sort of
bouncing this scan off the web server,

579
00:30:23.740 --> 00:30:26.720
well the web server is part of the
organization, it's probably allowed to go

580
00:30:26.720 --> 00:30:29.690
through that firewall and talk to
this node that we're trying to scan.

581
00:30:29.690 --> 00:30:30.890
>> That's exactly right.

582
00:30:30.890 --> 00:30:32.350
>> So a lot of benefits to
doing a scan like this.

583
00:30:32.350 --> 00:30:35.730
>> Yeah, and as you see,
here it's done, didn't take too long,

584
00:30:35.730 --> 00:30:38.460
we did it in 76.38 seconds.

585
00:30:38.460 --> 00:30:40.510
Look at NMAP rocking and rolling there.

586
00:30:40.510 --> 00:30:45.240
And we're getting all the wonderful
ports that we normally would, but

587
00:30:45.240 --> 00:30:46.960
we're not holding a smoking gun.

588
00:30:46.960 --> 00:30:48.350
Our zombie is.

589
00:30:48.350 --> 00:30:49.920
That's just what Mike was talking about.

590
00:30:49.920 --> 00:30:52.660
We have no fingerprint on this whatsoever.

591
00:30:52.660 --> 00:30:55.150
They would have to
investigate the zombie and

592
00:30:55.150 --> 00:30:58.090
see connections coming from us from there.

593
00:30:58.090 --> 00:31:02.570
But you'd have to be a good, it would be
like wow this is a key loss maybe someone

594
00:31:02.570 --> 00:31:06.280
ran NMAP from this and scanned our network
and that's why we're getting this.

595
00:31:06.280 --> 00:31:07.100
They wouldnt know.

596
00:31:07.100 --> 00:31:10.660
It would take a really good investigator
to figure out that that's exactly what

597
00:31:10.660 --> 00:31:11.370
was happening.

598
00:31:11.370 --> 00:31:15.880
Plus there would need to be some sort of
logging on that machine maybe not because

599
00:31:15.880 --> 00:31:20.550
of it's nature but we got all of
our ports showing us back up and

600
00:31:20.550 --> 00:31:24.020
we've got a lot of great open ports
there and we never had to touch it.

601
00:31:25.200 --> 00:31:28.440
I did give you the general
overview on how this works.

602
00:31:28.440 --> 00:31:33.340
I ran another scan earlier back when I was
building this, to show you good people.

603
00:31:33.340 --> 00:31:37.012
To run a real scan against the network
takes a little bit of time,

604
00:31:37.012 --> 00:31:39.812
especially when you're
looking at the output.

605
00:31:39.812 --> 00:31:42.402
You can add this line
to any of your scans,

606
00:31:42.402 --> 00:31:44.777
as this one helps very specifically.

607
00:31:44.777 --> 00:31:47.798
We used Wire Shark in the past to
show you the data passing through and

608
00:31:47.798 --> 00:31:50.034
the packets and
all the cool stuff inside of that.

609
00:31:50.034 --> 00:31:53.453
So you can actually do that
with nmap to an extent as well,

610
00:31:53.453 --> 00:31:56.070
you don't need Wireshark installed.

611
00:31:56.070 --> 00:32:02.825
All you have to do is add,
I think I have to put it over here,

612
00:32:02.825 --> 00:32:08.690
--packet-trace, if I'm not mistaken.

613
00:32:08.690 --> 00:32:11.410
When you add that to it, look at
all that data that's going through.

614
00:32:11.410 --> 00:32:13.640
These are all the actual packets
that are being passed and

615
00:32:13.640 --> 00:32:14.900
it's doing it live at fire.

616
00:32:14.900 --> 00:32:17.634
Right, so I'm just gonna kill that
cuz it's giving me sea sickness.

617
00:32:17.634 --> 00:32:19.630
>> [LAUGH]
>> And

618
00:32:19.630 --> 00:32:22.720
I've already captured all
the pertinent output for a scan, so

619
00:32:22.720 --> 00:32:26.900
we can walk through it really quickly and
see the detail of what's happening here.

620
00:32:26.900 --> 00:32:30.829
So I've got this little file,
where did all the text file go?

621
00:32:30.829 --> 00:32:35.620
There we go, right here, I've even color
coded it for us to help with this.

622
00:32:35.620 --> 00:32:36.430
Let me zoom in.

623
00:32:38.220 --> 00:32:42.778
So testing with the zombie,
six probes are sent.

624
00:32:42.778 --> 00:32:46.280
So initially and
that actually sent six probes.

625
00:32:46.280 --> 00:32:49.580
Remember I was talking about earlier
about how nmap tries to be robust,

626
00:32:49.580 --> 00:32:50.470
it tries to be consistent.

627
00:32:50.470 --> 00:32:54.300
Tries to make sure what it's telling you
is what it's supposed to be telling you.

628
00:32:54.300 --> 00:32:55.690
That's why it sent six probes.

629
00:32:55.690 --> 00:32:59.290
It's verifying that this
is an idle machine and

630
00:32:59.290 --> 00:33:02.110
that it is being incremented
in the way that we need.

631
00:33:02.110 --> 00:33:07.058
So when we see these six probes,
so here's a probe from

632
00:33:07.058 --> 00:33:12.080
.1 to .138 our zombie, and
then it replied, a probe.

633
00:33:12.080 --> 00:33:13.450
Then reply, a probe reply,

634
00:33:13.450 --> 00:33:17.510
and you'll notice that each one
of these increments by one.

635
00:33:17.510 --> 00:33:20.590
Letting me know that's
an actually an idle machine and

636
00:33:20.590 --> 00:33:24.130
the incrementation is as I need it.

637
00:33:24.130 --> 00:33:28.100
So, we know that the host
is a good zombie.

638
00:33:28.100 --> 00:33:32.920
Then it does the ID idle scan using
this zombie and the port that it uses.

639
00:33:32.920 --> 00:33:34.990
So in this scan, I use port 80.

640
00:33:34.990 --> 00:33:38.580
And it says it's spoofs four packets.

641
00:33:38.580 --> 00:33:43.380
This is what you didn't get to see
inside of my little diagram, right?

642
00:33:43.380 --> 00:33:45.980
Because it's a bit of too much
information at that point in time.

643
00:33:45.980 --> 00:33:49.720
Actually spoofs four packets
from the target to the zombie.

644
00:33:50.900 --> 00:33:51.730
Why is it do this?

645
00:33:51.730 --> 00:33:56.290
To verify that it will continue to
increment in the way that we want it to.

646
00:33:56.290 --> 00:34:00.190
So you'll notice it sends this four and
then it increments by four.

647
00:34:00.190 --> 00:34:04.270
So I think the last one was,
yeah, there you go.

648
00:34:04.270 --> 00:34:04.940
Ding.

649
00:34:04.940 --> 00:34:07.000
Now it did have this other
packet that went in there,

650
00:34:07.000 --> 00:34:08.570
so we actually solve by five.

651
00:34:08.570 --> 00:34:11.200
But it continued to increment
in the way that we want, so

652
00:34:11.200 --> 00:34:14.070
there was a superfluous
packet in this scan.

653
00:34:14.070 --> 00:34:16.750
But still incremented by one and
that's what we were looking for.

654
00:34:16.750 --> 00:34:18.570
We continued to be consistent.

655
00:34:18.570 --> 00:34:19.340
Where did it go?

656
00:34:19.340 --> 00:34:23.730
So now, we jump down to
the start of the idle scan.

657
00:34:23.730 --> 00:34:25.000
Here it goes.

658
00:34:25.000 --> 00:34:30.208
From 138, from port 80,
to our target on port 80.

659
00:34:30.208 --> 00:34:32.999
I was only targeting port 80,
not all ports here,

660
00:34:32.999 --> 00:34:36.690
because that would increase the time
phenomenally, it can anyway.

661
00:34:38.170 --> 00:34:43.470
And then it sends another one on this port
and there was a reply from this port.

662
00:34:43.470 --> 00:34:47.440
And it increased by two, because
there were two probes, two sent back.

663
00:34:47.440 --> 00:34:48.090
Good to go.

664
00:34:49.090 --> 00:34:49.920
We're all good.

665
00:34:49.920 --> 00:34:52.470
And then we move down here,
the IP ID increased by two.

666
00:34:52.470 --> 00:34:54.530
The port is open or is it?

667
00:34:54.530 --> 00:34:58.370
It checks again,
to make sure that it actually is open,

668
00:34:58.370 --> 00:35:01.470
it wasn't just a flyer, right?

669
00:35:01.470 --> 00:35:04.550
Some it just happened to happen and
you got lucky.

670
00:35:04.550 --> 00:35:06.370
And you thought it was over and it's not.

671
00:35:06.370 --> 00:35:09.170
It wants consistent results,
so it checks it again.

672
00:35:09.170 --> 00:35:14.072
And as you can see,
consistent checking, right there.

673
00:35:14.072 --> 00:35:18.877
For every probe sent there
is a proper response, so

674
00:35:18.877 --> 00:35:22.579
that's what we're looking for here.

675
00:35:22.579 --> 00:35:25.696
And then it says that, here we go,

676
00:35:25.696 --> 00:35:30.337
discovered port 80 is open and
it runs very well.

677
00:35:30.337 --> 00:35:32.370
So there's a lot going
on behind the grasp.

678
00:35:32.370 --> 00:35:36.510
Especially when you send this
out to multiple ports like what

679
00:35:36.510 --> 00:35:39.888
we did just a second ago,
there was a lot a ports that were open.

680
00:35:39.888 --> 00:35:43.210
It starts breaking them down to verify,
because there's gonna be open ports,

681
00:35:43.210 --> 00:35:45.570
there's gonna be closed
ports in all of those.

682
00:35:45.570 --> 00:35:47.820
So it says okay, here's what I start with.

683
00:35:47.820 --> 00:35:49.050
I got open ports and closed ports.

684
00:35:49.050 --> 00:35:51.070
Well, lets brake it down into two chunks.

685
00:35:51.070 --> 00:35:54.770
And then it gets open ports and closed
ports and breaks it down into four chunks.

686
00:35:54.770 --> 00:35:58.970
And continues to filter it down for
that consistency sake until it

687
00:35:58.970 --> 00:36:02.950
only has open ports and
closed ports in a consistent manner.

688
00:36:02.950 --> 00:36:06.292
Then it says these ports are filtered,
these ports are open and

689
00:36:06.292 --> 00:36:07.390
here is the output state.

690
00:36:07.390 --> 00:36:11.400
And you get that consistency and
we never touch the machine.

691
00:36:11.400 --> 00:36:14.549
We are free and clear, clean as
a preacher's sheets, as they like to say.

692
00:36:14.549 --> 00:36:16.334
>> [LAUGH]
>> Right, we are good to go,

693
00:36:16.334 --> 00:36:18.203
[INAUDIBLE] the driven snow.

694
00:36:18.203 --> 00:36:19.299
No one will ever suspect us.

695
00:36:19.299 --> 00:36:23.210
So Mike, that is an IP ID idle scan.

696
00:36:23.210 --> 00:36:24.860
In my opinion, very, very cool.

697
00:36:24.860 --> 00:36:25.520
>> Absolutely.

698
00:36:25.520 --> 00:36:26.970
It's a really cool scan,

699
00:36:26.970 --> 00:36:30.840
like we used to talking about the fact
that you can be really stealthy.

700
00:36:30.840 --> 00:36:33.750
Trying to scan that target machine and
bouncing it off of that zombie.

701
00:36:33.750 --> 00:36:37.060
And really cool explanation,
Daniel, great diagrams and

702
00:36:37.060 --> 00:36:41.480
a great demonstration really breaking
it down, it's a rather complex process.

703
00:36:41.480 --> 00:36:41.980
>> It is.

704
00:36:43.510 --> 00:36:47.630
>> Having a zombie, hitting that target,
trying to look at those, the IP IDs and

705
00:36:47.630 --> 00:36:51.750
determine their incremental or
how they're going about incrementing.

706
00:36:51.750 --> 00:36:53.160
A lot of pieces to it.

707
00:36:53.160 --> 00:36:54.520
Great explanation.

708
00:36:54.520 --> 00:36:55.460
Made perfect sense.

709
00:36:55.460 --> 00:36:58.180
I think we can all go out now and
do an IP idle scan and

710
00:36:58.180 --> 00:37:02.060
understand what we're doing and what
the results are that we're getting back.

711
00:37:02.060 --> 00:37:03.390
And stay stealthy about it.

712
00:37:03.390 --> 00:37:06.530
>> That's right, just don't do it on other
people's systems without their permission.

713
00:37:06.530 --> 00:37:07.300
>> That's right [LAUGH].

714
00:37:07.300 --> 00:37:08.611
>> All right.
>> Cuz in case you do get caught,

715
00:37:08.611 --> 00:37:09.980
in some way shape or form.

716
00:37:09.980 --> 00:37:10.970
That could be bad for you.

717
00:37:10.970 --> 00:37:11.920
>> This is Daniels.

718
00:37:11.920 --> 00:37:12.910
>> Yeah, you telling me.

719
00:37:12.910 --> 00:37:13.760
>> It looks so fun.

720
00:37:13.760 --> 00:37:15.670
So yes, always have permission.

721
00:37:15.670 --> 00:37:18.450
All right Daniel, we appreciate that,
again great demonstration there,

722
00:37:18.450 --> 00:37:20.410
hope everybody out there enjoyed watching.

723
00:37:20.410 --> 00:37:23.400
Signing off for ITProTV,
Ive been your host Mike Roderick.

724
00:37:23.400 --> 00:37:24.050
>> Im Daniel Lowry.

725
00:37:24.050 --> 00:37:26.151
>> And we'll see you next time.

726
00:37:26.151 --> 00:37:30.987
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Dan continue their exploration of the different type of scans that can be performed on your networks with Nmap, specifically the FTP bounce scans.
episodes.title: Advanced Port Scanning FTP Bounce
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.030 --> 00:00:14.997
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITPRO.TV.

3
00:00:14.997 --> 00:00:16.538
I'm your host Wes Bryan and

4
00:00:16.538 --> 00:00:20.511
we're coming back at you with a very
fun series continuing on in NMap.

5
00:00:20.511 --> 00:00:24.610
That's right and joining us back in the
studios is none other than Mr. Dan Lowrie.

6
00:00:24.610 --> 00:00:25.940
Dan how are you doing, sir?

7
00:00:25.940 --> 00:00:29.312
>> I'm doing great, I'm so glad to be back
because you know how much I love the NMap.

8
00:00:29.312 --> 00:00:33.014
It's so much fun to scan networks,
try to find machines and

9
00:00:33.014 --> 00:00:35.400
maybe some exploitable avenues.

10
00:00:35.400 --> 00:00:38.320
That being said we're back with
another one of our advanced

11
00:00:38.320 --> 00:00:41.520
port scanning types of scans
that we have inside of NMap.

12
00:00:41.520 --> 00:00:44.830
We took a look at IP ID idle scan,
very, very cool.

13
00:00:44.830 --> 00:00:49.630
This kinda goes along with the same vein,
today we're talking about the FTP bounce

14
00:00:49.630 --> 00:00:53.530
scan, and you're thinking, wow, that does
sound pretty cool, that's a little crazy

15
00:00:53.530 --> 00:00:56.020
there, we're gonna use FTP, we're gonna
bounce it around, it's gonna be good?

16
00:00:56.020 --> 00:00:57.630
Yeah, that's exactly what we're gonna do.

17
00:00:57.630 --> 00:00:59.600
So, grab onto your hats and hold on for

18
00:00:59.600 --> 00:01:03.610
the ride because let's just jump right
in and start talking about FTP bounce.

19
00:01:03.610 --> 00:01:07.990
The great thing is that I do have
a simple diagrams menu for you,

20
00:01:07.990 --> 00:01:10.883
a little illustration I created to help us

21
00:01:10.883 --> 00:01:15.778
better understand what the heck is
going on inside an FTP bounce scan.

22
00:01:15.778 --> 00:01:20.822
And basically what we're gonna do is again
much like than the way we used IPID idle

23
00:01:20.822 --> 00:01:26.163
scan where we used an intermediary to scan
machines for us because we're either being

24
00:01:26.163 --> 00:01:31.527
firewalled or we don't want to have such
a fingerprints on that machine itself.

25
00:01:31.527 --> 00:01:33.437
We're gonna do the same
thing with FTP bounce.

26
00:01:33.437 --> 00:01:39.587
And it's gonna exploit a feature
that's found in some FTP servers.

27
00:01:39.587 --> 00:01:44.177
And I say, a feature, very loosely
because, well, it allows FTP bouncing.

28
00:01:44.177 --> 00:01:47.347
And that's not something that you
typically want on your network.

29
00:01:47.347 --> 00:01:52.170
So it's good for us to be able to use
NMap to find devices on our network

30
00:01:52.170 --> 00:01:56.810
that will allow for an FTP bounce,
so we can stop that from happening.

31
00:01:56.810 --> 00:01:59.490
And then if we're trying
